{{Infobox book| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = 100 Things Successful People Do | image = 100 Things Successful People Do - UK Paperback and Hardback editions side by side.jpg | caption = | author = [[Nigel Cumberland]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom & United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[self help]], [[leadership]], [[self-development]] | publisher = [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray Learning]], [[Hodder & Stoughton]], Nicolas Brealey, [[Hachette UK]] | release_date = August 11, 2016 (hardcover), May 4, 2017 (paperback), | media_type = [[Hardcover]], [[Paperback]], [[Audiobook]] and [[E-book]] | pages = 224 (Hardcover 1st edition) | isbn = 978-185-7-88662-7 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living''''' is a self-help guide by [[Nigel Cumberland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6978123.Nigel_Cumberland |title=Nigel Cumberland (Author of 100 Things Successful People Do) |publisher=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Nigel-Cumberland/e/B0034P71X2/ref=dp_byline_cont_book_1 |title=Nigel Cumberland: Books, Biogs, Audiobooks, Discussions |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref><ref>https://www.hodder.co.uk/search.page?SearchText=nigel+cumberland</ref>
==Publication== The book was published in August 2016 by [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray Learning]] in the UK, a part of [[Hodder & Stoughton]] (imprint of [[Hachette UK]]).<ref>{{cite web|author=Time remaining -- days -- hours -- minutes -- seconds |url=https://www.hodder.co.uk/books/detail.page?isbn=9781473635067 |title=Nigel Cumberland - 100 Things Successful People Do - Hodder & Stoughton |publisher=Hodder.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> The US edition<ref>{{cite web|author=Barnes & Noble |url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/100-things-successful-people-do-nigel-cumberland/1124655804?ean=9781857886627 |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living by Nigel Cumberland, Hardcover | Barnes & Noble® |publisher=Barnesandnoble.com |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> came out in October 2016 published by another Hachette UK imprint, Nicolas Brealey Publishing. The paperback version<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/100-Things-Successful-People-Exercises/dp/1473635055/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr= |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Little Exercises for Successful Living: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9781473635050: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> was published in the UK in May 2017 with a US edition coming out in late 2017. The book has a foreword written by [[Marshall Goldsmith]]. It has featured in various suggested reading lists in the mainstream media.<ref>http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/health/723684/Self-help-book-selection-Autumn-2016</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jenna Farmer |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/books/non-fiction-books/best-books-for-entrepreneurs-2018-beginners-all-time-a8277266.html |title=9 best books for entrepreneurs |publisher=The Independent |date=2018-03-28 |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref>
Translated editions of the book include in [[Dutch language|Dutch]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Nigel Cumberland (Author) |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/9047010795/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1489115930&sr=8-12&keywords=Nigel+Cumberland |title=100 dingen die succesvolle mensen doen: Slim werken en prettig leven: Amazon.co.uk: Nigel Cumberland: 9789047010791: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> [[Romanian language|Romanian]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.librariaverona.ro/produse/100-de-pasi-pentru-o-viata-de-succes-autor-nigel-cumberland-editura-niculescu/7430 |title=100 DE PASI PENTRU O VIATA DE SUCCES AUTOR NIGEL CUMBERLAND EDITURA NICULESCU - Dezvoltare personala - Libraria Verona - Librarie Online - Carti la preturi mici |publisher=Librariaverona.ro |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> [[Russian language|Russian]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mann-ivanov-ferber.ru/books/ne-zhalej-ni-o-chem/ |title=Не жалей ни о чем (Найджел Камберленд) — купить в МИФе |publisher=Mann-ivanov-ferber.ru |date= |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> and [[Slovak language|Slovak]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.databazeknih.cz/knihy/100-veci-ktore-robia-uspesni-ludia-343943 |title=100 vecí, ktoré robia úspešní ľudia - Nigel Cumberland | Databáze knih |publisher=Databazeknih.cz |date= |accessdate=2018-06-17}}</ref> Upcoming translations include into [[Arabic]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Indonesian language|Indonesian]], [[Korean language|Korean]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]]<ref>http://anthearights.com/html/upload/files/doc_pages/78/bg/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1/lbf17%20hodder%20+%20jm%20non%20fic1.pdf</ref> and [[Bengali language|Bangla]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|title=সফল ব্যক্তিদের ১০০ জীবনচর্চা|last=Tuba, translator of [[Bengali language|Bangla]] version|first=Bushra Amin|date=|website=প্রিয়.কম|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171120050709/https://www.priyo.com/search?key=%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%AB%E0%A6%B2%20%E0%A6%AC%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%A4%E0%A6%BF%E0%A6%A6%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0%20%E0%A7%A7%E0%A7%A6%E0%A7%A6%20%E0%A6%9C%E0%A7%80%E0%A6%AC%E0%A6%A8%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%B0%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%9A%E0%A6%BE|archive-date=2017-11-20|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-10-02|df=}}</ref>
The book is available to be used in schools for the [[visually impaired]] in the United States through the [[Bookshare|bookshare service]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Bookshare: Homepage |url=https://www.bookshare.org/browse/book/1395852?returnPath=L2Jyb3dzZS9sYXRlc3Q/bW9kdWxlTmFtZT1wdWJsaWMmc29ydE9yZGVyPVRJVExFJmFkZGVkPU1PTlRIJmxpbWl0PTEwMCZvZmZzZXQ9MA%3D%3D |title=100 Things Successful People Do: Habits, Mindsets and Activities For Creating Your Own Success Story |publisher=Bookshare |date=2016-10-25 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==Contents== The book's 100 chapters each cover in a couple of pages one of the 100 things that the author suggests successful people do. A reviewer writes: "the book, subtitled Little Exercises For Successful Living, is easily digestible (perhaps even as a tip a day), with each spread over two pages – the first explaining the concept and the second featuring practical exercises and activities to apply it to your life."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/the-life/book-review-unlearn-it-all-to-move-ahead |title=Book review: Unlearn it all to move ahead | The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=2016-09-06 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref> Another adds: "each secret to success is a powerful reminder of the ways you can make your life – and other's – more satisfied, at work, at home and in your relationships, with your health, wealth and in retirement."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/successful-leaders-little-secrets-659239.html |title=Successful leaders' little secrets - Business - Arabian- Business -.com |publisher=Arabianbusiness.com |date=2017-01-17 |accessdate=2017-05-14}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox building | name = 10 East 40th Street | former_names = | alternate_names = Mercantile Building | status = Completed | image = 10 E 40th Street NYC.jpg | image_alt = | image_size = | caption = 10 East 40th Street from the main branch of the New York Public Library | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | altitude = | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | location = | address = | location_town = | location_country = | coordinates = {{coord|40.751592|-73.981323|region:US-NY|format=dms|display=inline}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | completion_date = 1929 | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 2002 | height = {{Convert|632|ft|m|0}} | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | top_floor = | observatory = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = 48 | floor_area = {{convert|350000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | main_contractor = | architect = | architecture_firm = [[Ludlow and Peabody]] | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | designations = | parking = | url = | embedded = | references = <ref>{{ctbuh|1892}}</ref> }} '''10 East 40th Street''' or the '''Mercantile Building''' is a skyscraper located in the [[Murray Hill, Manhattan|Murray Hill]] section of [[New York City]], between [[Fifth Avenue]] and [[Madison Avenue]], taking the width of the block between [[39th Street (Manhattan)|39th]] and [[40th Street (Manhattan)|40th street]]s. Designed by [[Ludlow and Peabody]] and built by [[Jesse H. Jones]], it was finished in 1929 and is an example of [[Renaissance Revival architecture]].<ref name =emporis/> When it was built, it was the fourth-tallest tower in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title=World's tallest buildings in 1930|url=http://www.ctbuh.org/Portals/0/Tallest/CTBUH_Tallest_1930.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226042600/http://www.ctbuh.org/Portals/0/Tallest/CTBUH_Tallest_1930.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-12-26}}</ref>
It was previously known as the Chase Tower, after its first tenant, [[Chase Brass and Copper Company|Chase Brass & Copper]]. Its owner until his death in 1938 was [[Frederick William Vanderbilt]].
It is {{Convert|632|ft|m|0}} high, with 48 floors, and contains {{convert|350000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of office or mixed-use space.<ref name=emporis>{{Cite web|title=Mercantile Building|url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=mercantilebuilding-newyorkcity-ny-usa|publisher=Emporis.com|accessdate=2008-07-12}}</ref> In September 2002, the building's lobby was renovated, restoring the {{convert|15|ft|m|adj=on}} ceilings.
Current tenants include the [[Morocco|Moroccan]] consulate. ==Last building on the direct current grid== On November 14, 2007, the building became the final site to be removed from [[Thomas Edison|Thomas Edison's]] original [[direct current]] grid in New York City.<ref>{{cite news | last = Lee | first = Jennifer 8. | authorlink = Jennifer 8. Lee | title = Off Goes the Power Current Started by Thomas Edison | work = New York Times | date = 2007-11-14 | url = http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/11/14/off-goes-the-power-current-started-by-thomas-edison/ | accessdate = 2009-09-04}}</ref>
The building was completed in 1929 when 90 percent of the electricity in lower Manhattan was direct current.<ref>http://magazine.ieee-pes.org/mayjune-2013/history-8/</ref> In that year New York Edison announced plans that it was going to convert the entire system to [[alternating current]].<ref>http://magazine.ieee-pes.org/mayjune-2013/history-8/</ref> The last 2 [[rotary converter]] substations generating direct current (at West 26th and West 39th Street) were retired in 1977 and the DC conversions were handled by solid-state [[rectifier]] units. The 2007 event shifted the responsibility for providing the conversion from Con Edison to the building via a local converter. Many of the buildings built in 1929 and before still use direct current with the local converter -- most notably for elevators. New York City's subway system which uses a [[third rail]] electric system is still direct current (with the MTA providing the local converters from AC to DC.<ref>http://magazine.ieee-pes.org/novemberdecember-2013/history-10/</ref>
==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in New York City]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Orphan|date=December 2015}}
'''Anders Midtgaard''' is a Danish entrepreneur, speaker and artist. He is the co-founder of [[Hopin Academy]] in Ghana. Hopin Academy is a for-profit educational organization based in [[Tamale]], [[Ghana]] that is open to anyone. Open 24 hours a day, Hopin Academy derives its name from its educational philosophy as a school designed for students to "hop in and hop out," rather than having strictly organized timetable structures. Hopin Academy offers courses in writing, design, film and entrepreneurship. Hopin Academy also provides training to NGOs, government organizations, and other schools, such as the [[Bryn Mawr College]] and Olive School of Journalism.
== Public speaker ==
Anders Midtgaard is also a speaker on issues related to [[learning]], idea-generation and creativity. He spoke in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]], in January 2014 at the personalitöö konverents<ref>http://www.aripaev.ee/uudised/2014/01/20/aripaeva-personalikonverents-tulekul-pohjapanevad-muutused</ref><ref>http://www.reklaam.ee/uudised/anders-midtgaard-koige-kovema-haalega-karjujad-pole-usaldusvaarsed</ref><ref>http://majandus24.postimees.ee/2656898/taani-visionaar-opetab-inimestele-oma-ideede-muumist</ref> held by national business paper [[Äripäev]]. The underlining theme in his speaks being that the key to success in both learning and any [[creative process]] is to set goals and create a safe space for [[enthusiasm]] and playfulness.
== Artist ==
As a musician,<ref>http://www.incendiarymag.com/albumreviews/narkohund/narkohund_%E2%80%93_love_agency</ref> artist and filmmaker,<ref>https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3855812/</ref> Anders Midtgaard has worked in [[Denmark]],<ref>http://www.dfi.dk/faktaomfilm/person/da/231444.aspx?id=231444</ref> Estonia <ref>http://online.le.ee/2013/07/02/roostal-tuleb-taani-paev/</ref> and the United States. His works was latest picked in the summer of 2015 for an exhibition on [[Surveillance]] at the Nave Gallery in [[Somerville, Massachusetts]].<ref>http://navegallery.org/wp/survey-without-surveillance-2/</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = '''[[Knight|Sir]]''' | name = Jayantilal Keshavji Chande | honorific_suffix = '''[[Order of the British Empire|KBE]]''' | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jayantilal Keshavji Chande | birth_date = {{birth date|1928|05|07|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|04|07|1928|05|07|df=y}} | monuments = | residence = Dar es Salaam, Tanzania | nationality = [[Tanzania]]n | other_names = JK Chande | citizenship = Tanzania | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Pune]] | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = A Knight in Africa: Journey from Bukene | style = | home_town = [[Bukene, Tanzania|Bukene]], Tanzania | salary = | net_worth = US$431 Million (July 2017) | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = Jayalaxmi Madhvani, Mama Chande | children = 3 | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = [[Order of the British Empire|KBE]]
[[Pravasi Bharatiya Samman]] | website = {{URL|andychande.com}} | module = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | influences = | influenced = | religion = | denomination = | ethnicity = | box_width = }} [[Knighthood|Sir]] '''Jayantilal Keshavji "Andy" Chande''' [[Order of the British Empire|KBE]] (7 May 1928 – 7 April 2017) (aka '''Andy Chande''') was a prominent [[Tanzania]]n businessman, philanthropist and a [[freemason]]. He was widely respected for all the positive things which he did within the country, such as he's heavy hand in developing a better education system, but also being a captain of industry who was able to transcend the Tanzanian market.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecitizen.co.tz/News/Prominent-businessman-Andy-Chande-dies-at-88/1840340-3881192-format-xhtml-125tikkz/index.html|title=Prominent businessman Andy Chande dies at 88|date=2017-04-07|work=The Citizen|access-date=2018-07-09|language=en}} ==Background== He was the Chairman of the Board of Governors of [[Shaaban Robert Secondary School]] and President of the Dar es Salaam Secondary Education Society. He was also the Honorary Trustee of Indian School - Dar es Salaam. He received the President’s Golden Century Citation from [[Rotary International]] for his continued dedication and commitment in 1995/1996. He also received the ‘Service Above Self’ award in 1998 from Rotary International in recognition of his years of work for the foundation. In 2003 he was appointed as a trustee of the Rotary Foundation and in 2004 appointed as Chairman of the Rotary Foundation of the United Kingdom. Vincent. In 2003 he received the ‘Hind Ratna’ award from [[I.K. Gujral]], the former Indian Prime Minister. The International Congress of Non-Resident Indians (NRI) then declared him to be the ‘non-Resident Indian of the year’. He was also given the Pride of India Gold Award by the NRI Institute in London. He was made an Honorary [[Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire]] on 29 August 2003, the first of its kind given to a Tanzanian citizen. On 9 January 2005, The President of India, [[Abdul Kalam|Dr APJ Abdul Kalam]] honoured him with the prestigious [[Pravasi Bharatiya Samman]] Award. On 10 August 2007, the [[Swahili language|Swahili]] translation of his book '''A Knight in Africa (Shujaa Katika Afrika: Safari Kutoka Bukene)''' was launched at the [[Shaaban Robert Secondary School]] hall, by [[President of Tanzania]], [[Jakaya Kikwete]]. Other prominent figures in attendance included: *2nd President of Tanzania, [[Ali Hassan Mwinyi]] *3rd President of Tanzania, [[Benjamin Mkapa]] *The Canadian High Commissioner to Tanzania, Dr Andrew McAlister[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927230602/http://www.dailynews-tsn.com/page.php?id=8106] ==Awards== * [[Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire]], 2003 * [[Pravasi Bharatiya Samman]], 2005 ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://andychande.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=28/ A Knight in Africa] ==External links== *{{Official website}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chande, Andy}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Tanzanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Savitribai Phule Pune University alumni]] [[Category:Tanzanian Freemasons]] [[Category:Tanzanian people of Indian descent]] {{Tanzania-bio-stub}} {{Africa-business-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Chemical industry in Poland''' - one of the key branches of the processing industry which includes:
* [[organic chemistry|organic]] [[Chemistry & Industry|chemistry industry]] – manufactures products on the basis of [[carbohydrate]]s, [[wood]], [[rubber]], [[fat]]s and other [[organic substance]]s,<ref>{{cite book |author = Zachodniopomorski Uniwersytet Technologiczny w Szczecinie |title = Analiza sytuacji rynkowej dla działalności gospodarczej na obszarze województwa zachodniopomorskiego dla branży chemicznej |location = Gdańsk |date = 2011|page= 11 |isbn =}}</ref> * [[Hypothetical types of biochemistry|non-organic]] chemistry industry – products manufactured on the basis of non-organic substances, e.g. [[mineral]]s and [[ore]]s.
Chemical industry in terms of tons of production can be divided into:<ref>{{cite book |author = Zachodniopomorski Uniwersytet Technologiczny w Szczecinie |title = Analiza sytuacji rynkowej dla działalności gospodarczej na obszarze województwa zachodniopomorskiego dla branży chemicznej |location = Gdańsk |date = 2011|page= 4 |isbn =}}</ref>
* great chemistry - the name refers to the production size of millions tons a year; great chemistry includes the production of [[Fertilizer|fertilisers,]] [[fuel]]s, [[plastic]]s (''mainly [[Plasticizer|plasticisers]]'') and [[industrial gas]]es;<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chem.uw.edu.pl/people/AMyslinski/nowy/EChJ/wyklad_01.pdf | title = Chemia stosowana, odpady i zarządzanie chemikaliami | publisher = chem.uw.edu.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> * small chemistry - production on a smaller scale - dozens of tons; this sector includes mainly chemistry with high added value and more expensive production, e.g. medicaments,cosmetics, [[cleaning agent]]s; * chemical processing - processing finished half-products: by mixing, packing, thermal treatment and other methods.
Chemical industry is characteristic of the high capital intensity and low labour consumption, for this reason, the most of operations are automated.
== Chemical industry products== Divisions within the Polish chemical industry, by types of products and companies, include:
* [[Coke (fuel)|Coking]] industry<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tchie.uni.opole.pl/PECO11_1/PL/Machnowska_PECO11_1.pdf | title = Przemysł koksowniczy w aspekcie ochrony środowiska | publisher = tchie.uni.opole.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.min-pan.krakow.pl/se/pelne_teksty22/czII/k22_warzecha_z.pdf | title = Koksownictwo polskie na tle światowego przemysłu koksowniczego | publisher = min-pan.krakow.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cire.pl/pliki/2/karcz.pdf | title = 50% rynku Europy Zachodniej dla Polski? Koksowe divide et impera | publisher = cire.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> — for example: the coking plants "Radlin", "Jadwiga", "Dębieńsko" in [[Bytom]], [[Zdzieszowice]], [[Wałbrzych]], [[Zabrze]], and [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]]; and [[foundry|foundries]] in [[Kraków]], [[Częstochowa]], and Dąbrowa Górnicza. *[[Cleaning products]] industry. * [[Fertilizer]]s industry <ref>{{cite web | url = http://biznes.pl/magazyny/przemysl/nawozy-z-przyszloscia-czy-polska-chemia-nadaza/7c8y1 | title = Nawozy z przyszłością. Czy polska chemia nadąża? | publisher = biznes.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160719094336/http://biznes.pl/magazyny/przemysl/nawozy-z-przyszloscia-czy-polska-chemia-nadaza/7c8y1 | archivedate = 2016-07-19 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chemiaibiznes.com.pl/aktualnosc/przemysl-nawozowy-kluczowy-dla-rozwoju-rolnictwa | title = Przemysł nawozowy kluczowy dla rozwoju rolnictwa | publisher = chemiaibiznes.com.pl | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> — for example: [[Grupa Azoty S.A.]], with plants in [[Puławy]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.pulawy.com/pl/nowy-nawoz-pulaw/ | title = Nowy nawóz z "PUŁAW" | publisher = blog.pulawy.com | accessdate = 2016-06-22 | language = Polish }}</ref> [[Police, West Pomeranian Voivodeship|Police]], [[The history of Zakłady Azotowe in Tarnów-Mościce|Tarnów-Mościce]], [[Kędzierzyn-Koźle]], Chorzów, Gdańsk,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blog.pulawy.com/pl/fosfory-wyprodukuja-nawozy-odpadow/ | title = "Fosfory" wyprodukują nawozy z revision.text:
{{about|a series of horse-racing and business-simulation video games|The 2007 film starring Zac Efron|The Derby Stallion}} {{Infobox video game series |title =Derby Stallion |creator =[[Hiroyuki Sonobe]] |artist =[[Susumu Matsushita]] |image =Derby Stallion II Coverart.png |caption =Cover art of the second game in the series (released in 1994) |developer =[[ASCII (company)|ASCII Entertainment]] |publisher =[[Nintendo]] |genre =[[Racing video game|Horse racing]]
[[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] |released =21 December 1991 |spinoffs = }} The {{nihongo|'''''Derby Stallion'''''|ダービースタリオン}} - also known in Japan by the [[Portmanteau#Japanese|portmanteau abbreviation]] {{nihongo|'''DerbyStal'''|ダビスタ}} - video games are a series of genre-merging [[Racing video game|horse-racing]] and [[business simulation game]]s originally created by [[ASCII Entertainment]], and released by [[Nintendo]]. The series comprises 21 games, spans more than 10 console platforms, and is the best-selling horse racing series of all time with total sales topping more than 4 million in Japan.http://www.the-magicbox.com/Chart-JPPlatinum.shtml ==Gameplay== The ultimate goal of the player in the ''Derby Stallion'' games is to win the title of GI ([[Group One|Group I]]) Racer. To do this, the player must attempt to develop the greatest stock of horses that he can in order to have the greatest chance at each of the weekday and holiday races that compose the 1-year racing schedule of the fictitious "SRA" (an abbreviation of [[Sonobe, Kyoto|Sonobe]] Racing Association) group. Between races, the player engages in numerous business simulation, farm simulation, and role-playing activities. ''Derby Stallion'' games have evolved as newer members of the series have been added, allowing players greater and greater control over every aspect of the horse-raising business. As such, the player must now [[horse racing|race horses]] and place racing bets, manage the working of a [[stable]]s and/or [[ranch]], select different studs and broodmares for [[Horse breeding|breeding]], learn to [[Horse breaking|break]] and [[Horse training|train]] horses, and set up advantageous [[horse trading|horse trades]] or sales, among other duties. Players must also make critical decisions about appropriate ages to race horses, [[Horse breed|breeds]] to pursue, and the timing of events to coincide with race dates. As the player improves the stock of his horses, his racing statistics, and his position in the world of the horse business, his Group Ranking increases until he reaches the goal of Group I at which point he has won the game. The games also allow the player to continue playing after the top goal has been met. ''Derby Stallion'' games all feature a single-player mode, however much effort has been put into making the games as versatile as possible for multiplayer capabilities. Multiplayer functions allow players to trade or complete sales between themselves, to set up breeders' agreements, and to race against opponents. To accomplish this, various methods have been used to exchange data from the earliest password code exchange to online connectivity with PCs, [[Satellaview]] exchange (via 8MB memory packs and [[Satellaview#Compatible application cartridges|slotted application cartridge]]), and [[Randnet|RANDnetDD]] service.''[http://ign64.ign.com/articles/067/067393p1.html GDC: Miyamoto Unveils Camera Connection]''. IGN. 18 March 1999. Other methods of data exchange that have been developed include various Game Boy-Link connections''[http://www.videogames.yahoo.com/news-1097130 Derby Stallion Lives]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' IGN. 2000. and telephone satellite connections (for players using DoCoMo phones). ==Series== {| class="wikitable" !Name!!Release Date!!Systems |- | style="text-align: center; top" | [[Nintendo Switch|Switch]] |- |} ==Individual games== ===Derby Stallion II=== {{Infobox video game |title = Derby Stallion II |image = |caption = |developer = [[ASCII Entertainment]] |publisher = ASCII Entertainment |released = {{vgrelease|JP|February 18, 1994}} |genre = [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicom]] }} '''''Derby Stallion II''''' is a complex horse farm business [[simulation game]] that was released in 1994 exclusively for the Japanese market. It was created for the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super Famicom]]. In the game, the player must breed horses that can be trained to become [[horse racing]] champion [[thoroughbred]]s. However, the player starts out with a limited amount of money and must sell horses at a profit once they are [[advanced age|too old to race anymore]]. ===Derby Stallion 64=== {{Infobox video game | title = Derby Stallion 64 | image = derbystallion64.jpg | caption = Cover art | developer = Parity Bit | publisher = [[Media Factory]] | released = {{vgrelease|JP|August 10, 2001}} | genre = [[Racing video game|Racing]]
[[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] | modes = [[Single player]], [[multiplayer]] | platforms = [[Nintendo 64]] }} {{nihongo|'''''Derby Stallion 64'''''|ダービースタリオン64 Dābī Sutarion 64}} is a horse racing [[Nintendo 64]] game that is also a business simulation game. It released in 2001 exclusively for the Japanese market. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Derby Stallion (Series)}} [[Category:1994 video games]] [[Category:2001 video games]] [[Category:ASCII games]] [[Category:Kadokawa Dwango franchises]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:FM Towns games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:Japan-exclusive video games]] [[Category:Horse-related video games]] [[Category:NEC PC-9801 games]] [[Category:Nintendo 64 games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:PlayStation 2 games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Portable]] [[Category:Racing video games]] [[Category:Sega Saturn games]] [[Category:Super Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Video games scored by Koichi Sugiyama]] [[Category:Video games scored by Manami Matsumae]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video game franchises]]

{{Notability|Organizations|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox organization | name = Design Institute of Australia | native_name = | named_after = | image = Design_Institute_of_Australia_Logo.gif | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = DIA | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date|1947|df=y}} | founder = | founding_location = [[Melbourne, Australia]] | extinction = | merger = | type = Australian Public Company | tax_id = | registration_id = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = 27 Derby Street, Collingwood VIC 3066, Australia | coords = | region = | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = | sec_gen = | leader_title = National President | leader_name = Claire Beale | leader_title2 = CEO | leader_name2 = Jo-Ann Kellock | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|www.dia.org.au}} | remarks = | formerly = Society of Designers for Industry,
Industrial Design Institute of Australia | footnotes = }} The '''Design Institute of Australia''' ('''DIA''') is an [[Australian]] organisation that represents [[designers]] in Australia.{{cite web | url=http://www.dia.org.au/index.cfm?id=10 | title=The DIA | accessdate=13 May 2015}} The DIA acts as a professional body representing all disciplines of design, and undertakes work such as the promotion of ethical standards for the design industry, as well as promoting co-operation between individual designers.{{cite web | url=http://www.design.org.au/index.cfm?id=12 | title=The DIA Strategic Plan | accessdate=13 May 2015}} ==History== The organisation was founded as the Society of Designers for Industry in 1947, and first incorporated as the Industrial Design Institute of Australia on 15 August 1958, with chapters in [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]], [[New South Wales]] and [[South Australia]]. The institute joined the [[International Council of Societies of Industrial Design|ICSID]]{{cite web | url=http://www.design.org.au/index.cfm?id=78 | title=ICSID | accessdate=13 May 2015}} in 1967. They joined [[International Council of Design]] in 1980 and then, on 20 December 1982, the organisation was again renamed to the Design Institute of Australia, as it is today. On 1 July 1998, the organisation merged with the Society of Interior Designers of Australia, and the Australian Textile Design Association; becoming a National rather than Federal body.{{cite web | url=http://www.design.org.au/index.cfm?id=204 | title=History of the DIA | accessdate=13 May 2015}} ==See also== *[[International Council of Societies of Industrial Design]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.design.org.au/index.cfm Official website] [[Category:Design institutions]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Australian design]] [[Category:1947 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1947]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2011}} [[File:BT Edinburgh Park.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[BT Group|BT]] building, designed by [[Bennetts Associates]] architects]] '''Edinburgh Park''' is a [[business park]] in [[South Gyle]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]]. It is west of the city, near [[Edinburgh Airport]] and the [[Edinburgh City Bypass]]. It was opened in 1995. The layout of the park was masterplanned by [[United States|American]] architect [[Richard Meier]]. [[Edinburgh Park railway station]], which is on the [[Glasgow to Edinburgh via Falkirk Line]], opened in December 2003. [[Edinburgh Trams]] began serving the park on 31 May 2014 with stops at Edinburgh Park Station, Edinburgh Park Central and The Gyle. It is not to be confused with [[South Gyle|Gyle Park]] nearby, site of the former [[Gogarloch]]. The park has a bar/grill, nursery, and several sculptures, including busts of famous Scottish poets, many of them [[Socialism|socialists]].{{cite book|title=Literary Corstorphine: A reader's guide to West Edinburgh|date=2017|last=Bell|first=Raymond MacKean|location=Edinburgh|publisher=Leamington Books|isbn=9780244644406}} {{See also|Edinburgh#Economy|l1='The Economy' section in 'Edinburgh'}} ==Businesses== [[File:Somhairlemacgilleain.jpg|thumb|200px|Herm of [[Sorley MacLean]], the [[Scottish Gaelic|Gaelic]] poet, in the Lochside development]] Businesses with a presence in the Edinburgh Park include: *[[Aegon UK]] *[[Lloyds Banking Group]] *[[BT Group|BT]] *[[Diageo]] *[[HSBC Bank (Europe)|HSBC]] *[[John Menzies]] *[[JPMorgan Chase|JP Morgan]] *[[Fujitsu]] *[[The Royal Bank of Scotland|RBS]] *[[Regus]] *[[Sainsbury's Bank]] *[[NetCracker Technology EMEA Ltd]] *[[WSP Group]] == Transport == === Road === ==== [[Edinburgh City Bypass|Edinburgh City Bypass (A720)]] ==== '''Junction 10: Hermiston Gait'''
The M8 terminates here at a roundabout under the bypass with access into Edinburgh Park and South Gyle from the south. '''Junction 11: Gogar Junction'''
The end of the city bypass where it links with the A8. This junction provides access into Edinburgh Park and South Gyle from the north. === Rail === The main [[Glasgow to Edinburgh via Falkirk Line|Edinburgh-Glasgow railway line]] runs along the southern border of the park, where it is served by [[Edinburgh Park railway station|Edinburgh Park station]] . === Tram === '''Edinburgh Park Central''' tram stop is situated in the parkland between Lochside Avenue and Lochside Crescent. {{s-rail-start|noclear=yes}} {{s-rail|title=Edinburgh Trams}} {{Rail line|previous=[[Edinburgh Park railway station|Edinburgh Park station]]
''towards [[York Place tram stop|York Place]]'' |next=[[The Gyle Shopping Centre|Gyle Centre]]
''towards [[Edinburgh Airport tram stop|Airport]]'' |route=''York Place - Edinburgh Airport''|col={{temporary rail colour|8D122A}} }} {{s-end}} === Buses === ==== [[Lothian Buses]] ==== * 2, 12, 18, 20, 21, 22, 35, 63 ==== [[First Scotland East]] ==== * X2 ==Recent developments== A 120-bed [[Premier Inn]] opened at Lochside Avenue in February 2012.http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g186525-d2545476-r125333706-Premier_Inn_Edinburgh_Park_The_Gyle-Edinburgh_Scotland.html#REVIEWS It is next to [[Edinburgh Park railway station|Edinburgh Park station and tram stop]]. ==External links== *[http://www.edinburghpark.co.uk/ Edinburgh Park official website] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Areas of Edinburgh}} [[Category:Areas of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Edinburgh]] [[Category:Richard Meier buildings]] [[Category:Business parks of Scotland]] [[Category:1995 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Edinburgh Trams stops]]

An '''electric utility''' is a company in the [[electric power industry]] (often a [[public utility]]) that engages in [[electricity generation]] and [[Electricity retailing|distribution of electricity]] for sale generally in a [[regulated market]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Electric|url=http://snavely-king.com/page/regulated-electric|website=snavely-king.com|publisher=Snavely King Majoros & Associates|accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> The electrical utility industry is a major provider of energy in most countries.
Electric utilities include [[Investor-owned utility|investor owned]], [[Public ownership|publicly owned]], [[cooperatives]], and [[nationalized]] entities. They may be engaged in all or only some aspects of the industry. [[Electricity market]]s are also considered electric utilities—these entities buy and sell electricity, acting as brokers, but usually do not own or operate generation, transmission, or distribution facilities. Utilities are regulated by local and national authorities.
Electric utilities are facing increasing demands <ref name=one>By Candace Lombardi, CNET. “[http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10458148-54.html Utilities: Green tech good for planet, bad for business].” February 23, 2010.</ref> including [[Electrical grid#aging infrastructure|aging infrastructure]], reliability, and regulation.
==Organization==
===Power transactions=== An electric power system is a group of generation, transmission, distribution, communication, and other facilities that are physically connected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Electricity Basics|url=http://www.science.smith.edu/~jcardell/Readings/uGrid/ElecPwrSys%20Operations/EPS_Overview_EIA.pdf|website=science.smith.edu|publisher=Smith College|accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> The flow of electricity within the system is maintained and controlled by dispatch centers which can buy and sell electricity based on system requirements.
===Executive compensation=== {{Globalize|date=February 2016}}
The [[executive compensation]] received by the executives in utility companies often receives the most scrutiny in the review of [[operating expenses]]. Just as regulated utilities and their governing bodies struggle to maintain a balance between keeping consumer costs reasonable and being profitable enough to attract investors, they must also compete with private companies for talented executives and then be able to retain those executives.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Joskow|first1=Paul|last2=Rose|first2=Nancy|last3=Wolfram|first3=Catherine|title=Political Constraints on Executive Compensation: Evidence From the Electric Utility Industry|journal=RAND Journal of Economics|date=1996|volume=27|issue=1|pages=165–182}}</ref>
Regulated companies are less likely to use incentive-based [[remuneration]] in addition to base salaries. Executives in regulated electric utilities are less likely to be paid for their performance in bonuses or [[stock options]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> They are less likely to approve compensation policies that include incentive-based pay.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The compensation for electric utility executives will be the lowest in regulated utilities that have an unfavorable regulatory environment. These companies have more political constraints than those in a favorable regulatory environment and are less likely to have a positive response to requests for rate increases.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bryan|first1=Stephen|last2=Hwang|first2=Leeseok|title=CEO Compensation In A Regulatory Environment: An Analysis Of The Electric Utility Industry|journal=Journal of Accounting, Auditing & Finance|date=1997|volume=12|issue=3|pages=223–251}}</ref>
Just as increased constraints from regulation drive compensation down for executives in electric utilities, [[deregulation]] has been shown to increase remuneration. The need to encourage risk-taking behavior in seeking new investment opportunities while keeping costs under control requires deregulated companies to offer performance-based incentives to their executives. It has been found that increased compensation is also more likely to attract executives experienced in working in competitive environments.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bryan|first1=Stephen|last2=Lee-Seok|first2=Hwang|last3=Lilien|first3=Steven|title=CEO Compensation After Deregulation: The Case Of Electric Utilities|journal=Journal of Business|date=2005|volume=78|issue=5|pages=1709–1752}}</ref>
The [[Energy Policy Act of 1992]] removed previous barriers to wholesale competition in the electric utility industry. Currently 24 states allow for deregulated electric utilities: Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Texas, Virginia, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Connecticut, Delaware, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Montana, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, and Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deregulated States|url=http://www.alliedpowerservices.com/deregulated-states.shtml|website=alliedpowerservices.com|publisher=Allied Power Services|accessdate=18 July 2014}}</ref> As electric utility monopolies have been increasingly broken up into deregulated businesses, executive compensation has risen; particularly incentive compensation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Arya|first1=Avinash|last2=Sun|first2=Huey-Lian|title=Impact of Deregulation in CEO Compensation: The Case of Electric Utilities|journal=American Business Review|date=2004|volume=22|issue=1|pages=27–33}}</ref>
'''Oversight'''
Oversight is typically carried out at the national level, however it varies depending on financial support and external influences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gala.gre.ac.uk/3754/1/PSIRU_9253_-_2004-09-E-WEC.pdf|title=Electricity liberalisation: The beginning of the end|last=Thomas|first=Steve|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=December 3, 2016}}</ref> There is no existence of any influential international energy oversight organization. There does exist a World Energy Council, but its mission is mostly to advise and share new information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldenergy.org/about-wec/mission-and-vision/|title=Mission|website=www.worldenergy.org|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> It does not hold any kind of legislative or executive power. In the western hemisphere, many electric utility companies were under oversight from the United States and although the United States has, in the early 21st century, withdrawn from many of these countries. Several major energy utility companies are still under oversight from the United States.
'''[[Alternative energy]] promotion'''
Alternative energy has become more and more prevalent in recent times and as it is inherently independent of more traditional sources of energy, the market seems to have a very different structure. In the United States, to promote the production and development of alternative energies, there are many subsidies, rewards, and incentives that encourage companies to take up the challenge themselves. There is precedent for such a system working in countries like Nicaragua. In 2005, Nicaragua gave renewable energy companies tax and duty exemptions, which spurred a great deal of private investment.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/nation-world/world/article24772123.html|title=Nicaragua’s latest revolution: Becoming a green energy powerhouse|newspaper=mcclatchydc|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref>
The success in Nicaragua may not be an easily replicated situation however. The movement was known as Energiewende and it is generally considered a failure for many reasons.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2016/03/renewable-energys-global-growing-pains/|title=Renewable energy’s global growing pains|newspaper=Ars Technica|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> A primary reason was the fact that it was improperly timed and was proposed during a period in which their energy economy was under more competition.
'''Nuclear Energy'''
Nuclear energy may or may not be classified as a green source depending on the country. Although there used to be much more privatization in this energy sector, after the 2011 Fukushima district nuclear power plant disaster in Japan, there has been a move away from nuclear energy itself, especially for privately owned nuclear power plants.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rt.com/news/nuclear-state-private-japan/|title=Nuclear power: private vs state|newspaper=RT International|language=en-EN|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> The criticism being that privatization of companies tend to have the companies themselves cutting corners and costs for profits which has proven to be disastrous in the worst-case scenarios. This placed a strain on many other countries as many foreign governments felt pressured to close nuclear power plants in response to public concerns.<ref name=":0" /> Nuclear energy however still holds a major part in many communities around the world.
== Customer expectations == Utilities have found that it isn't simple to meet the unique needs of individual customers, whether residential, corporate, industrial, government, military, or otherwise. Customers in the twenty-first century have new and urgent expectations that demand a transformation of the electric grid. They want a system that increases a utility's capacity to use solar and wind to produce electricity. Customers also want a system that gives them new tools, better data to help manage energy usage, advanced protections against cyberattacks, and a system that minimizes outage times and quickens power restoration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dailyenergyinsider.com/source/11146-iei-event-emphasizes-efforts-utilities-serve-diverse-mix-customers/|title=IEI event emphasizes efforts by utilities to serve diverse mix of customers|last=Riley|first=Kim|date=2018-03-08|work=Daily Energy Insider|access-date=2018-03-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Consumer Advocate for Customers of Public Utilities]] *[[Electricity transmission]] *[[Rate Case]] *[[Rate base (energy)]]

{{Infobox magazine | title = Electronics | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[Trade magazine]] | frequency = | circulation = | publisher = | founder = | founded = | firstdate = {{Start date|1930|April}} | finaldate = 1995 | company = [[McGraw-Hill Education]]: until 1988
[[Verenigde Nederlandse Uitgeverijen]]: 1988-1989
[[Penton Media]]: 1989-1995 | country = [[United States]] | based = | language = English | website = | issn = 0013-5070 | oclc = }} '''''Electronics''''' was an [[United States|American]] [[trade journal]] that covered the radio industry and its later spin-offs in the mid-to-late 20th century. Its first issue was dated in April 1930."Introducing: The New, Biweekly Electronics", ''Electronics'', May 1992, p. 22 The periodical was published under the title ''Electronics'' until 1984, when it changed temporarily to the new title ''ElectronicsWeek'', but then reverted to the original title ''Electronics'' in 1985. The ISSN for the corresponding periods are: {{ISSN|0013-5070}} for the 1930–1984 issues, {{ISSN|0748-3252}} for the 1984–1985 issues with title ''ElectronicsWeek'', and {{ISSN|0883-4989}} for the 1985–1995 issues. It was published by [[McGraw-Hill]] until 1988, when it was sold to the Dutch company [[Verenigde Nederlandse Uitgeverijen|VNU]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/22/business/sale-by-mcgraw-hill.html Sale By McGraw-Hill] VNU sold its American electronics magazines to [[Penton Media|Penton Publishing]] the next year.[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/penton-media-inc-history/ Penton Media, Inc. History] Generally a bimonthly magazine, its frequency and page count varied with the state of the industry, until its end in 1995. More than its principal rival ''[[Electronic News]]'', it balanced its appeal to managerial and technical interests (at the time of its 1992 makeover, it described itself as a magazine for managers). The magazine was best known for publishing the April 19, 1965 article by [[Intel]] co-founder [[Gordon Moore]], in which he outlined what came to be known as [[Moore's Law]]. ==Intel's hunt for Moore's original article== On April 11, 2005, Intel posted a $10,000 reward for an original, pristine copy of the ''Electronics Magazine'' where Moore's article was first published.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=technologyNews&storyID=8148789 |work=Reuters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050413085535/https://www.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type%3DtechnologyNews%26storyID%3D8148789 |archivedate=April 13, 2005 }} The hunt was started in part because Moore lost his personal copy after loaning it out. It soon became apparent to librarians that their copies of the article were in danger of being stolen, so many libraries (including [[Duke University]] and the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]]) located and secured the articles. The [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] was not so lucky, however, as the day after Intel announced the reward, they found that one of the two copies they owned was missing.[http://networks.silicon.com/webwatch/0,39024667,39129574,00.htm silicon.com]'', 2005 Intel has stated that they will only purchase library copies of the article from the libraries themselves, and that it would be easy to determine as most libraries [[book binding|bind]] their old magazines, requiring to cut the article from the bound book if a thief were to sell the article.{{cite web |url=http://newsobserver.com/news/ncwire_news/story/2332707p-8710798c.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2005-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050824034043/http://newsobserver.com/news/ncwire_news/story/2332707p-8710798c.html |archivedate=2005-08-24 |df= }} NC News Wire Intel ultimately awarded the prize to David Clark, an engineer living in [[Surrey]], [[England]] who had decades of old issues of ''Electronics Magazine'' stored under his floorboards.{{cite news |title=Moore's Law original issue found |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/technology/4472549.stm |publisher=BBC News |date=2005-04-22 |accessdate=2009-04-10}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commons category inline|Electronics (magazine)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Electronics}} [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:Defunct magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1930]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1995]] [[Category:American science and technology magazines]] [[Category:Professional and trade magazines]] [[Category:American monthly magazines]]

{{Infobox sailor | name = | image = Crew of 6 Metre Norna.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Anker in ''Norna'', second from the right. | headercolor = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|yyyy|mm|dd}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|death year|death month|death day|birth year|birth month|birth day}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | agent = | height = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | spouse = | life_partner = | other_interests = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | country = | sport = | disability = | disability_class = | rank = | event = | collegeteam = | universityteam = | league = | league_type = | club = | team = | turnedpro = | partner = | former_partner = | coach = | retired = | coaching = | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | paralympics = | highestranking = | pb = | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport| Men's [[Sailing at the Summer Olympics|sailing]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1928 Summer Olympics|1928 Amsterdam]] | [[Sailing at the 1928 Summer Olympics|6 metre class]]}} | show-medals = | updated = }}
'''Erik Anker''' (15 October 1903 – 16 August 1994) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[yacht racing|sailor]] and businessperson.
==Early life and Olympics== He was born in [[Berg, Østfold]] as a son of [[Johan Anker]].<ref name=sref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/an/erik-anker-1.html|title=Erik Anker|publisher=Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> He was a brother of [[Christian August Anker (1896–1982)|Christian August Anker]], and a stepson of [[Nini Roll Anker]].<ref name=snl2>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Anker|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=|publisher=|location=|url=http://www.snl.no/Anker|language=Norwegian|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> He was married to Swedish citizen Eva Esther Laurell.<ref name=hvem>{{cite encyclopedia|year=1973|title=Anker, Erik|encyclopedia=[[Hvem er hvem?]]|editor=Steenstrup, Bjørn|publisher=Aschehoug|location=Oslo|url=http://runeberg.org/hvemerhvem/1973/0023.html|page=23|language=Norwegian|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref>
In sailing he represented the [[Royal Norwegian Yacht Club]]. At the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] he won the gold medal as crew member of the Norwegian boat ''Norna'' in the 6 metre class event.<ref name=sref/> The crew was Johan Anker, Erik Anker, [[Olav V of Norway|Crown Prince Olav of Norway]] and [[Håkon Bryhn]].<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Erik Anker|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=|publisher=|location=|url=http://www.snl.no/Erik_Anker|language=Norwegian|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> Anker later chaired the Royal Norwegian Yacht Club from 1949 to 1951, and became an honorary member in 1977.<ref name=obit/> He was also a board member of the [[Nordic Sailing Federation|Scandinavian Sailing Federation]].<ref name=hvem/>
He [[examen artium|finished]] his secondary education in 1922. He studied at the business school in [[Neuchâtel]] until 1924, then studied economy at [[Ecole libre des sciences politiques]] from 1924 to 1925. He worked as an accountant and salesman in Agence des Pays du Nord in Paris between 1924 and 1929, and then, while also studying chemistry in [[Brussels]] he was a director of [[Societé Belge du Titane]] from 1929 to 1935. In 1935 he returned to Norway as director of exports in [[Norsk Aluminium Co]].<ref name=hvem/>
==Business executive== In 1937 he became director in [[Titan Co]] in [[Fredrikstad]]. From 1950 he was the chief executive, and also chairman of sister corporation in Europe until his retirement in 1969.<ref name=hvem/>
He chaired [[Fredrikstad]] commerce council from 1945 to 1956, and chaired local committees to administer bridge and railroad building. He was also [[consul (representative)|vice consul]] for [[Belgium]] in Østfold county from 1949 to 1959. During the [[occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany]] he eventually fled to [[Sweden during World War II|neutral Sweden]], and worked in the industry office of the [[Norwegian legation in Stockholm]] from 1944 to 1945. He was decorated with the [[Defence Medal 1940–1945]].<ref name=hvem/>
He chaired [[Studieselskapet for Norsk Industri]] (1948–1951), the [[Royal Norwegian Council for Scientific and Industrial Research]] (1968–1973, formerly board member 1950–1960) and [[Norsk Hydro]] (1970–1974, board member since 1968). He was deputy chair of [[Store Norske Spitsbergen Kulkompani]] (1945–1954), board member of [[Federation of Norwegian Industries (1919–1989)|Federation of Norwegian Industries]] (1956–1964) and the Norwegian [[International Chamber of Commerce]] branch.<ref name=hvem/><ref>{{cite news|title=NTNF øker arbeidet på energisektoren|date=5 December 1973|work=[[Aftenposten]]|page=24|language=Norwegian}}</ref>
He was decorated as a Knight, First Class of the [[Order of St. Olav]] (1960), Knight of the [[Order of Leopold II]] and Officer of the [[Order of the Crown (Belgium)|Belgian Order of the Crown]].<ref name=hvem/> In 1973 he was promoted to Commander of the Order of St. Olav. He died in 1994.<ref name=obit>{{cite news|title=Erik Anker (obituary)|last=Tandberg|first=Truls|date=25 August 1994|work=[[Aftenposten]]|page=13|language=Norwegian}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{Advert|date=January 2014}} {{third-party|date=January 2014}} {{one source|date=January 2014}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2014}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Factiva | logo = FactivaLogo 2011.PNG | type = | foundation = 1999 | location = | key_people = | industry = | products = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = [[News Corp]] | num_employees = | parent = [[Dow Jones & Company]] | subsid = | homepage = http://www.factiva.com | footnotes = }}
'''Factiva''' is a [[business]] information and [[research]] tool owned by [[Dow Jones & Company]]. Factiva [[News aggregator|aggregates]] content from both [[license]]d and [[free content|free sources]], and provides organizations with search, alerting, dissemination, and other [[information management]] capabilities. Factiva products provide access to more than 32,000 sources (such as [[newspapers]], [[Academic journal|journals]], [[magazines]], television and radio [[:wikt:transcript|transcript]]s, [[photograph|photos]], etc.) from nearly every country worldwide in 28 languages, including more than 600 continuously updated [[newswire]]s.
{{citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==History== The company was founded as a joint-venture between [[Reuters]] and [[Dow Jones & Company]] in May 1999 under the Dow Jones Reuters Business Interactive name,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsbreaks.infotoday.com/nbreader.asp?ArticleID=17964 |title=Dow Jones Interactive, Reuters Business Briefing Merged into Dow Jones Reuters Business Interactive |accessdate=15 May 2010 |publisher=Information Today, Inc |date=17 May 1999 }}</ref> and renamed Factiva six months later. Timothy M. Andrews, a longtime Dow Jones executive, was founding president and chief executive of the venture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsbreaks.infotoday.com/nbreader.asp?ArticleID=17879 |title=Factiva: The New Name for Dow Jones Reuters Business Interactive |accessdate=15 May 2010 |publisher=Information Today, Inc |date=8 November 1999 }}</ref>
Mr. Andrews was succeeded by Clare Hart in January 2000, another longtime Dow Jones executive, who was serving as Factiva’s vice president and director of global sales.
It developed modules with [[Microsoft]], [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle Corp.]], [[IBM]] and [[Yahoo!]] [https://web.archive.org/web/20051001063212/http://search.yahoo.com/subscriptions]. Factiva has also partnered with EuroSpider, [[Comintelli]], [[PeopleSoft]], MediaMap, Biz360, ChoicePoint, [[BTRadianz]], AtHoc, and Reuters. Factiva has also been included as of March 2003 in [[Microsoft Office|Microsoft's Office 2003]] program as one of the News research options within the Research Pane.
In 2005, Factiva acquired two private companies: [[London]]-based 2B Reputation Intelligence Ltd. and [[Denver, Colorado]]-based [[Taxonomy (general)|taxonomy]] services and software firm, [[Synapse, the Knowledge Link Corporation]]. 2B was a technology and consulting business, specializing in media monitoring and reputation management. Synapse provided taxonomy management software, pre-built taxonomies and taxonomy-building and indexing services.
This acquisition brought with it Synaptica, the taxonomy management software tool developed by Synapse, and Taxonomy Warehouse, a website developed by Synapse. Both Synaptica and Taxonomy Warehouse were developed by Factiva after the acquisition and are now owned by Dow Jones.
In 2006, Reuters sold its 50 percent share of Factiva to Dow Jones. Factiva was integrated into the Enterprise Media Group within Dow Jones.<ref>http://markets.financialcontent.com/stocks/news/read/300150/Dow_Jones_to_buy_rest_of_Factiva_for_$160_mln</ref> Clare Hart was the executive vice president of this operating group.
In 2007, Factiva was included as a Dow Jones company sold to [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s News Corp.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/printer_friendly_wires/2007Jul31/0,4675,DowJonesMurdochGlance,00.html|title=FOXNews.com - Thumbnails of Dow Jones and News Corp. - Business And Money - Business News - Financial News|author=|date=|website=www.foxnews.com|accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref>
Factiva provides searching by free-text, as well as region, subject, author, industry and company metadata. Searches can be further filtered by publication, language and date range.
Factiva offers a number of enterprise integration option<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://web.jinfo.com/go/sub/article/71874|title=Product Review of NewsEdge.com (Value - Competitors, Development & Pricing)|work=Jinfo|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref>s, including a fully comprehensive web services API, the Factiva Developers Kit. This toolkit allows organisations to embed Factiva content and services within enterprise workflow applications.
In 2008 Dow Jones launched the website Synaptica Central to highlight the Synaptica tool and to discuss controlled vocabularies and semantic technologies etc.
In 2012, Dow Jones announced<ref>[http://dowjones.com/pressroom/releases/2012/1242012-DJChampionsNewGenerationofUXforFactiva-0095.asp DOW JONES & COMPANY CHAMPIONS NEW GENERATION OF USER EXPERIENCE FOR FACTIVA CUSTOMERS]. Dow Jones Press Release, December 4, 2012</ref> a new search platform for its digital network based on technology licensed from [http://www.marklogic.com MarkLogic® Corporation].
==Competition== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2014}} Factiva global competitors include [[D&B]], [[InsideView]], [[LexisNexis]], NewsEdge<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsedge.com|title=NewsEdge|author=|date=|website=www.newsedge.com}}</ref>, Semantic Visions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.semantic-visions.com|title=Taking the Pulse of the Planet|author=|date=|website=www.semantic-visions.com}}</ref>, LexisNexis Corporate Affiliations<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corporateaffiliations.com|title=Home|author=|date=|website=www.corporateaffiliations.com}}</ref>, [[Salesgenie]].com, [[Zoominfo]] and [[ISI Emerging Markets]].
There are local competitors, specialized in European and Asian languages, with better coverage in some geographies (French-speaking countries, Russian-speaking countries, Chinese-speaking countries...)
*French speaking countries : CEDROM-SNI/Europresse<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europresse.com|title=Veille et analyse d'informations stratégiques avec Europresse|author=|date=|website=Europresse}}</ref>, L'Argus de la Presse *Russian speaking countries : Medialogia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mlg.ru/|title=Медиалогия – мониторинг СМИ и СОЦМЕДИА|author=|date=|website=Медиалогия - система мониторинга СМИ}}</ref>, RussoScopie/Integrum WW<ref>{{cite web|url=http://russoscopie.com/integrum-russian-media-monitor/|title=Search Results for “Russia/integrum-russian-media-monitor/” – NamSor Blog|author=|date=|website=russoscopie.com}}</ref>, Eastview<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastview.com/|title=East View Information Services Home Page|author=|date=|website=www.eastview.com}}</ref>, SCAN<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scan-interfax.ru/|title=СКАН - система мониторинга СМИ от Интерфакса|author=|date=|website=www.scan-interfax.ru}}</ref> ([[Interfax]]) *Chinese speaking countries: [http://www.wisers.com Wisers]
