revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Mark Scheinberg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1973}} | birth_place = Israel | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = [[Israeli-Canadian]] | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = [[Isle of Man]] | education = | occupation = Investor | salary = | networth = [[United States dollar|$]]4.8 billion (March 2018)<ref name=Forbes>{{cite web|title=Mark Scheinberg|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/mark-scheinberg/|website=Forbes|accessdate=7 March 2017}}</ref> | spouse = | parents = [[Isai Scheinberg]] | children = | relatives = | website = }}
'''Mark Scheinberg''' (born 1973)<ref name=Forbes/> is an Israeli-Canadian businessman and investor with investments in various sectors including real estate and luxury hospitality. He is the co-founder and former co-owner of the online gambling company [[PokerStars]], which was sold in 2014 to [[Amaya Gaming]] for $4.9 billion.<ref name=Bloomberg/>
==Early life== Mark Scheinberg was born in [[Israel]] in 1973, moving to [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada at the age of 13 with his [[Isai Scheinberg|family]].<ref name=Forbes/> They settled in the town of [[Richmond Hill, Ontario|Richmond Hill]] in the 1980s.<ref name=GlobeMail>{{cite news|last1=Freeze|first1=Colin|title=A look at the mysterious Canadian founder of PokerStars|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/a-look-at-the-mysterious-canadian-founder-of-pokerstars/article4171690/|accessdate=18 January 2015|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=22 April 2011}}</ref>
==Career== In 2001 Scheinberg founded [[PokerStars]] with his father [[Isai Scheinberg]], a computer programmer.<ref name=Forbes/><ref name=madrid/> During his tenure as CEO, PokerStars became the world’s largest online poker business and host to the world’s largest online tournament series,<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2010/02/10/internet-gambling-pokerstars-business-beltway-pokerstars.html#48c5db0575ba "PokerStars: Online Gambling's Quiet Giant"], ''Forbes,'' Nathan Vardi, February 10, 2010</ref> acquiring the [[Full Tilt Poker]] brand in 2012.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-07-31/pokerstars-strikes-u-dot-s-dot-deal-to-buy-full-tilt-poker "PokerStars Strikes U.S. Deal to Buy Full Tilt Poker"], ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'', Caroline Winter, July 31, 2012</ref> In August 2014,<ref>[https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/amaya-completes-acquisition-of-pokerstars-and-full-tilt-poker-515194841.html "Amaya Completes Acquisition of Pokerstars and Full Tilt Poker"], August 1, 2014, press release</ref> Oldford Group Ltd,<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2014/06/19/how-a-4-9-billion-purchase-of-pokerstars-could-change-online-poker-in-america/#78cc4821404b "How A $4.9 Billion Purchase Of PokerStars Could Change Online Poker In America"], ''[[Forbes]]'', Darren Heitner, June 19, 2014</ref> the PokerStars parent company, was acquired by the Canadian publicly listed company [[Amaya Gaming Group]] for $4.9 billion. Upon completion of the sale, Scheinberg exited the PokerStars group.<ref name=Bloomberg>{{cite news|last1=Palmeri|first1=Christopher|title=PokerStars’ Scheinberg Becomes Billionaire on Sale to Amaya|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-06-13/pokerstars-scheinberg-becomes-billionaire-on-sale-to-amaya-1-.html|accessdate=18 January 2015|work=Bloomberg|date=13 June 2014}}</ref> According to ''[[Forbes]]'', Scheinberg has a net worth of $4.8 billion as of June 2018.<ref name=Forbes/> As of May 2017, Scheinberg was the richest person on the Isle of Man.<ref name=man>{{cite news|title=Scheinberg now richest on the island|url=http://www.iomtoday.co.im/article.cfm?id=33459&headline=Scheinberg%20now%20richest%20on%20the%20island&sectionIs=news&searchyear=2017|accessdate=24 May 2017|work=IOM Today|date=5 May 2017}}</ref>
Via his investment company Mohari Hospitality,<ref name="CASINON">[http://www.casinonewsdaily.com/2017/11/07/pokerstars-founder-mark-scheinbergs-madrid-hotel-complex-open-doors-2019/ "PokerStars Founder Mark Scheinberg’s Madrid Hotel Complex to Open Doors in 2019"], ''Casino News Daily'', November 7, 2017</ref> in early 2017 Scheinberg became a major investor in Centro Canalejas Madrid, a real estate project in [[Madrid]], Spain.<ref name=madrid>{{cite news|title=PokerStars Founder Mark Scheinberg Invests in Spain’s Real Estate Market|url=http://www.casinonewsdaily.com/2017/05/17/pokerstars-founder-mark-scheinberg-invests-spains-real-estate-market/|accessdate=24 May 2017|work=Casino News Daily|date=17 May 2017}}</ref> Mohari purchased a 50% stake in the Centro for €225 million from the Grupo OHL subsidiary OHL Desarrollos and the industrial group Villa Mir, who both also retained stakes.<ref>[http://www.ohl.es/en/press-room/news/2017/february-2016/170209-ohl-desarrollos-and-gvm-sell-a-50-stake-in-centro-canalejas-madrid-to-the-businessman-mark-scheinberg-for-225-million-euro/ OHL Desarrollows and GVM Sell a 50 Percent Stake in Centro Canalejas Madrid to the Businessman Mark Scheinberg], OHL, February 9, 2017</ref> With an opening date set for 2019,<ref name="CASINON"/> the project involves the restoration of seven historic<ref name=Forbes/> adjacent buildings<ref name=madrid/> for residential, hotel and commercial use. With a large amount of retail space, the complex will also house the first [[Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts|Four Seasons]] hotel in Spain,<ref name="CASINON"/> and create 4,800 positions.<ref>[https://iberian.property/news/centro-canalejas-madrid-will-open-its-doors-at-the/ Centro Canalejas Madrid Will Open Its Doors at the Beginning of 2019], Iberian Property, November 10, 2017</ref>
In September 2017, a Canadian subsidiary of Mohari Hospitality acquired the Thompson Toronto hotel in downtown [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]].<ref>[http://www.lexpert.ca/article/mohari-canada-inc-purchases-thompson-hotel/ "Mohari Canada Inc. purchases Thompson Hotel"], ''Lexpert Magazine'', August 25, 2017</ref> The "boutique" hotel<ref>[http://www.thompsonhotels.com/hotels/toronto/thompson-toronto "Thompson Hotels"], Thompson Toronto</ref> has 105 rooms, event space, and restaurants and lounges.<ref>[https://www.hotelbusiness.com/thompson-toronto-sale-arranged-by-jll/ "Thompson Toronto Sale Arranged by JLL"], ''Hotel Business'', September 13, 2017</ref>
==Personal life== Scheinberg is single and lives in the [[Isle of Man]].<ref name=Forbes/>

{{Tone|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox organization |name = Marketing Research Association |image = MRA Logo med300w.png |image_border = |size = |alt = MRA Logo |caption = |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = MRA |motto = |formation = 1957 |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = <!-- focus as e.g. humanitarian, peacekeeping, etc --> |headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]] |location = [[United States]] |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = Worldwide |membership = 3,000 |language = English |leader_title = President<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20021106065514/http://www.mra-net.org/about/board.cfm MRA Board of Directors]</ref> <!-- |leader_name = President --> |main_organ = Volunteer Board of Directors |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.marketingresearch.org |remarks = }}
The '''Marketing Research Association''' ('''MRA''') was a [[501(c)(6)]] [[non-profit]], membership trade association, incorporated in New York state. Members were companies that specialized in, or had departments that specialized in, [[market research]], consumer opinion and related marketing intelligence. Individuals who were marketing research practitioners could also become members.
Located in [[Washington D.C.]] the Marketing Research Association was founded in 1957. The MRA's chief product was membership. It was also active in advocating industry positions on legislative and regulatory issues. In January, 2017, the Marketing Research Association merged with [[Council of American Survey Research Organizations|CASRO]] to form the Insights Association.
==Membership== Membership principally included access to a common [[code of conduct]] and set of [[best practices]]; industry-related news briefs and publications, including its trade-oriented magazine, Alert; invitation to MRA's annual conference and to meetings of its regional chapters; access to market research videos, online training seminars, papers and directories; access to professional certification; legislative updates; governmental advocacy; and access to an online jobs board. Annual membership dues are dependent on the applicant's company size and relationship to the marketing research industry. Some membership-only products are sold separately (i.e., not included in the annual membership fee). The organization said it has approximately 3,000 members.
==Conferences== MRA held three annual conferences, the Corporate Researchers Conference CRC St. Louis, The Insights & Strategies Conference ISC San Diego and The CEO Summit Napa Valley.
==Governmental Affairs== MRA's Governmental Affairs section monitored statutory and legislative issues that affected market researchers, such as consumer [[information privacy|data privacy]] legislation and court rulings in each of the 50 United States and in other countries, including [[social media]] legislation, legal issues pertaining to [[consumer privacy]] for medical care and prescriptions (such as [[HIPAA]]-related rulings), [[anti-spam]] legislation, telephone surveys, political polling, and similar issues. On topics such as the [[Telephone Consumer Protection Act]] (TCPA) of 1991, the [[Federal Trade Commission]]'s (FTC) and [[Department of Commerce]]'s support of rules restricting access to consumer data, and various Congressional consumer privacy acts, the MRA publicly advocated (i.e., lobbies legislators and other governmental officials to adopt) positions that support the organization's goals. Opposition to these positions generally cames from [[consumer rights]] organizations and their lobbyists.
==Professional Education== The [[University of Georgia]]'s online course, "Principles of Marketing Research," is based on an MRA-developed curriculum entitled "Market Research Core Body of Knowledge." Scholarships for this course were provided annually by the MRA to one or more qualifying applicants. The Marketing Research Association also offered a Professional Researcher Certificate (PRC) administered through the organization's website. Both of these programs were open to members at additional cost.
==Board of directors== The MRA Board of Directors included Jill Donahue, Chairman of the Board; Debby Schlesinger-Hellman, PRC, Immediate Past Chairman; Ted Donnelly, Ph.D., PRC, Vice Chair, Vaughn Mordecai, PRC, Treasurer; Dan Womack, PRC, Secretary; and David W. Almy, Chief Executive Officer. The Board also included six Directors at Large: Scott Baker, PRC, Janet Baldi, Jim Bryson, Jerry Haselmayer, Jeffrey Henning, PRC and Elizabeth Merrick.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.marketingresearch.org/ Official MRA Website] * [http://www.marketingresearch.org/conference/2015-corporate-researchers-conference Corporate Researchers Conference CRC St. Louis] * [http://www.marketingresearch.org/conference/2015-mra-insights-strategies-conference Insights & Strategies Conference ISC]

arrest by the [[US Army]] | birth_name = Max Ilgner | birth_date = {{Birth date|1899|6|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Biebesheim am Rhein]], [[Grand Duchy of Hesse]], [[German Empire]] | disappeared_date a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = Doctorate in political science | alma_mater = [[Goethe University Frankfurt]] | occupation = Business executive | years_active = | employer = [[IG citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Nazi Party]] | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = Spoliation and plunder | criminal_penalty = Three years imprisonment | criminal_status = | spouse = Erna Hällström | partner = | children = three | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Max Ilgner''' (born 28 June 1899 in [[Biebesheim am Rhein]] – died 28 March 1966 in [[Schwetzingen]]) was a [[Germany|German]] industrialist. He was a member of the board of [[IG Farben]] and held the title ''Wehrwirtschaftsführer'' or war economy leader under the [[Nazi regime]]. After the war, he was convicted by the Allies of "spoilation and plunder", but released almost immediately, and continued his career as a political lobbyist and business executive, becoming chairman of a Swiss chemical company.
==Early life== Ilgner came from an established military family, with his father and grandfather both officers, and followed in their footsteps by entering cadet school. He briefly served as a junior officer on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] at the very end of the [[First World War]].<ref name="Jeff154">Jeffreys, p. 154</ref> He then joined the [[Freikorps]] for a spell before being discharged from the new [[Reichswehr]] after its numbers were substantially reduced by the terms of the [[Treaty of Versailles]].<ref name="Jeff154"/>
The demobbed Ilgner took a doctorate in political science at the [[Goethe University Frankfurt]], having also studied [[metallurgy]] and [[chemistry]] at the Technical College of Charlottenburg.<ref name="memo">[http://www.wollheim-memorial.de/en/max_ilgner_18991966 Wollheim Memorial Max Ilgner (1899–1966)]</ref> He briefly worked in [[Stockholm]] following completion of his studies and whilst there he met Erna Hällström. The two were later married and had three children.<ref name="memo"/>
==Rise in IG Farben== Despite his extensive qualifications Ilgner found work hard to get in depressed post-war Germany, and so he called on his uncle [[Hermann Schmitz (industrialist)|Hermann Schmitz]], the financial chief at [[BASF]], who secured for Ilgner a position as a salesman at the chemical company.<ref name="Jeff154"/> In 1926, having worked for BASF for two years, Ilgner was given a new role working with Schmitz at a newly established central finance unit for IG Farben on [[Berlin]]'s [[Unter den Linden]]. Although little more than a messenger boy Ilgner built up a strong network of contacts and, with his uncle's support, advanced through the ranks at the company.<ref name="Jeff154"/>
By 1934 Ilgner had been appointed as a deputy member of the ''[[Vorstand]]'' of IG Farben and had a remit that gave him some control over not only financial and public relations decisions but also the company's dealings with central government.<ref name="Jeff154"/> He led two important subsections of the central finance unit, namely the Department of Economic Research (known as ''Vowi'') which was established in 1929 and dealt with overseas investment opportunities and the Department of Economic Policy (''Wipo'') which was set up in 1932, under [[Heinrich Gattineau]] and then Ilgner, to keep an eye on legal, foreign policy and taxation issues that might impact on the relationship between the company and the government.<ref name="Jeff154"/>
Ilgner's rapid rise, his naked ambition and the feeling that he was being pushed only because of his family connections made him unpopular with many of his fellow executives but Schmitz held too much power in the company for such objections to be raised publicly.<ref name="Jeff155">Jeffreys, p. 155</ref>
==Working with the Nazis== Ilgner was offered membership of the [[Nazi Party]] in 1933 but refused on the grounds that he wished to retain his membership of [[Rotary International]], an organisation that [[Joseph Goebbels]] had declared incompatible with [[Nazism]]. Nevertheless, Ilgner was happy to work closely with the fledgling Nazi regime and encouraged public support for Nazism by the company's factory workers.<ref name="Jeff155"/> He also worked with Goebbels in an attempt to get the Minister of Propaganda to tone down some of his rhetoric, which Ilgner believed was damaging Germany's reputation internationally, an initiative which initially enjoyed some success until Goebells became angry at Ilgner telling him what to do and broke off communication.<ref>Jeffreys, pp. 156-157</ref> Undeterred Ilgner hired the services of the [[United States|American]] public relations expert [[Ivy Lee]] to improve the reputation of [[Adolf Hitler]] on the world stage. After Lee's initial suggestion, the dropping of [[anti-Semitism]], was rejected out of turn by Hitler, they agreed on a programme of presenting Germany as a welcoming, historical destination to American investors whilst also plotting a policy of arranging for pro-Hitler articles to be added to American newspapers.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 157</ref> Ilgner's work was criticised by other ''Vorstand'' members, who felt that he was undertaking too much government propaganda and not enough work for IG Farben, but his initiatives won Hitler's approval and increasingly IG Farben's overseas offices also became centres of Nazi Party propaganda.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 158</ref> In return Ilgner was able to boost IG Farben's contracts with the government, notably their fading [[Leuna]] arm which was rejuvenated considerably when Ilgner was able to use contacts in the Reichswehr's Weapons Office to secure for this branch of the company the contract to produce fuel for the [[Luftwaffe]], which was being covertly built up in contravention of the Treaty of Versailles but which would have been discovered had they been forced to import large quantities of aircraft fuel.<ref>Jeffreys, pp. 161-162</ref> According to Ilgner's much later claims his influence amongst the Nazi hierarchy even saved the life of Gattineau on [[Night of the Long Knives]] after his fellow executive had been arrested due to his membership of the ''[[Sturmabteilung]]'' and his friendship with [[Ernst Röhm]].<ref>Jeffreys, p. 167</ref> Ilgner would finally join the Nazi Party in 1937.<ref>Hermann Weiß (ed.): ''Biographisches Lexikon zum Dritten Reich''. Fischer-Verlag, Frankfurt am Main, 1998, p. 22</ref>
Under Ilgner's direction IG Farben would also play a role in the annexation of the [[Sudetenland]] and the dismemberment of [[Czechoslovakia]]. Along with fellow executive [[Georg von Schnitzler]] Ilgner developed a scheme whereby IG Farben would fund pro-German newspapers in Czechoslovakia. The large scale publication of propaganda stories that accompanied the negotiations between Hitler and [[Neville Chamberlain]] helped to whip up strong support for the Nazis amongst the country's German community and the company continued to pour money into Sudeten German Relief Fund and the [[Sudetendeutsches Freikorps]]. When the fate of the country was sealed and the Nazis took over IG Farben were rewarded for their part in events by being allowed to take control of Aussiger Verein, a [[Prague]]-based chemical company that was the fourth largest in Europe, at a low price.<ref>Jeffreys, pp. 205-207</ref>
==World War II== Immediately after the outbreak of the [[Second World War]] Ilgner handed over the company's extensive collection of geological maps to the government, informing them of the locations across Europe where chemicals might be extracted.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 213</ref> As head of ''Vowi'' he had also built up extensive knowledge of IG Farben's main overseas competitors and he was able to supply the government with full details of the operations of [[Imperial Chemical Industries]], a British chemical company that Ilgner had one eye on in the event of [[Operation Sea Lion]] being launched.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 225</ref>
As the war dragged on a Nazi defeat began to look inevitable Ilgner took steps to safeguard his own future. After a bomb struck the Unter den Linten offices in January 1945 Ilgner announced that he could not work under such conditions and, taking all sensitive documented material with him, relocated his office to [[Frankfurt am Main]]. In fact Ilgner was simply trying to avoid falling into the hands of the [[Soviet Union]] and so moved westwards and whilst in Frankfurt ensured the disappearance of the incriminating documents he had taken with him.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 293</ref>
==Post-war== Ilgner was one of 24 executives of the company indicted for "spoilation and plunder" by the Americans on 4 May 1947 in what became known as the [[IG Farben Trial]]. Ilgner in particular was singled out for the leading role he played in German rearmament<ref>Jeffreys, p. 323</ref> and at the trial it was noted that he was the only executive who continued to fraternise openly with [[Carl Krauch]] who was bearing the bulk of the guilt due to his close relationship to [[Hermann Göring]].<ref>Jeffreys, p. 326</ref> Ilgner was one of nine defendants found guilty of "spoilation and plunder" in 1948, which was defined as the taking of property without the owner's full and non-coerced consent and was sentenced to three years in prison.<ref>Jeffreys, pp. 337-338</ref> However, he was released already in the same year.<ref>[http://www.wollheim-memorial.de/en/max_ilgner_18991966#cite_a Wollheim Memorial]</ref>
Ilgner announced his conversion to [[Christianity]] in prison and vowed to follow a missionary path following his release.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 345</ref> For a time he followed this path, undertaking work on behalf of the [[Evangelical Church of Westphalia]].<ref>Ernst Klee, ''Das Personenlexikon zum Dritten Reich. Wer war was vor und nach 1945'', Frankfurt am Main 2007, p. 278</ref> This did not prove to be long-lived however and instead he became a professional political lobbyist.<ref>Jeffreys, p. 346</ref> In 1955 he was appointed the chairman of the board at a chemical company in [[Zug]].<ref name="memo"/>
==Bibliography== *Diarmuid Jeffreys, ''Hell's Cartel: IG Farben and the Making of Hitler's War Machine'', Bloomsbury, 2009
==References== {{reflist}}

{{no footnotes|date=July 2014}}
'''Michael Tositsas''' is one of the Great Benefactors of Greece. He was born in [[Metsovo]] in 1787, and in 1806 he took over his father’s fur shop in [[Thessaloniki]], together with his brothers. After developing his business significantly, he sent his brothers to Egypt to open a branch there while he opened branches in [[Livorno]] and [[Malta]].
In 1820 he moved to Malta himself. His acquaintance with Egypt’s [[Mohammed Ali Tewfik|Prince Regent Mohammed Ali]] resulted in the Prince taking high esteem in him and appointing him his personal advisor as well as at the helm of the first state bank, the head of the Nile Riverboat company and administrator of his land.
Tositsas, who became one of Egypt’s most powerful landowners, also served as Greece’s first General Consul in [[Alexandria]] and is generally regarded as the father of [[Hellenistic religion|Hellenism]] of Egypt. He contributed to the establishment of the Greek Community and, together with his brothers, he helped the community develop significant educational and religious infrastructure. In 1854 he moved to Athens where he died in 1856. His charitable work was not limited to Alexandria but was equally important in Athens, Thessaloniki and his birthplace Metsovo. In his will he left vast amounts for aid for the poor and the support of hospitals, churches and schools. Among them the most notable ones are his contributions to the [[University of Athens]], the Arsakio School and the [[National Technical University of Athens]]. After his death, his wife Eleni continued his charity work by donating large amounts to educational and charity organizations as well as for the construction and completion of the National Technical University of Athens. His younger brother, Theodore, who also became very wealthy in Egypt, returned to Greece after the liberation from the Ottomans and donated the largest part of his wealth to foundations.
==Sources==
#G. Plataris, “Oi Tositsides sto Livorno” [The Tositsa family in Livorno], Epirotiko Imerologio 1984, pp. 199–206. #A. Politou, O Ellinismos kai I Neotera Aigyptos, Vol. A’, I istoria tou aigyptiotou ellinismou 1798-1927 [Greeks and modern Egypt, vol A, the history of Greeks of Egypt, 1798-1927] , publ. Grammata, Aleksandreia-Athens 1928-1930, 165-167, 172,175-176, 191-222, 237-240, 243,-247. #V. Skafidas, “Istoria tou Metsovou” [History of Metsovo], Epirotiki Estia 12/131, 132 (1963), pp. 194–200, 293-294 #A. Goudas, Vioi Paralliloi ton epi tis anagenniseos tis Ellados diaprepsanton andron [Parallel lives of the men who excelled during the Renaissance, Wealth and Commerce] , Vol. D’, ek tou typografeiou Ch. N. Philadelpheos, Athens 1871, 447-486. #I. Chatzifotis, “Oi Metsovites stin Aleksandreia” [The Metsovites in Alexandria], Minutes of the 1st conference of Metsovite Studies, Athens 1993, pp. 87–96 #G. Plataris-Tzimas, Kodikas Diathikon, Meizones kai elassones euergetes tou Metsovou [Log of Wills, Major and Minor Benefactors of Metsovo], publ. of the Prefecture of Ioannina and the City of Metsovo, Metsovo/Athens 2004, Vol. A’, pp. 179–207, Vol. B’ pp. 203–217, Vol. C’ pp. 69–71.

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Mick Beddoes 2015.jpg|thumb|right|Mick Beddoes]] '''Mick Malcolm Millis Beddoes''', widely known as '''Mick Beddoes''', is a Fijian politician and businessman from [[Nadi]], who led the [[United Peoples Party (Fiji)|United Peoples Party]] (formerly the '''United General Party''') from 2000 to 2013, and was the [[Leader of the Opposition (Fiji)|Leader of the Opposition]] at the time of the [[2006 Fijian coup d'état|military coup]] of 5 December 2006. He was also the Chief Executive of the [[World Netball Company]], and was Chairman of the organising committee for the 2007 [[World Netball Championships]], but announced his resignation on 24 January 2006, citing a possible conflict of interest, as his company would be working as a ground operator during the championships.
== First term as Leader of the Opposition ==
Beddoes won the [[West Central (General Electors Communal Constituency, Fiji)|West Central]] [[General electors|General Electors]] [[Communal constituencies|Communal constituency]], one of three reserved for ethnic minorities, for the United General Party in the 2001 [[Fijian general election, 2001|parliamentary election]]. Despite being the sole [[House of Representatives of Fiji|parliamentary]] representative of his [[List of political parties in Fiji|party]], he served as [[Leader of the Opposition (Fiji)|Leader of the Opposition]] from 2002 to 2004, because [[Mahendra Chaudhry]], leader of the [[Fiji Labour Party]] (the main opposition party) refused the position, demanding inclusion in the [[Cabinet of Fiji|Cabinet]] instead. Beddoes relinquished the role of Opposition Leader late in 2004, when Chaudhry finally gave up his quest for a Cabinet role and agreed to assume the leadership of the Opposition.
Beddoes's first stint as Opposition Leader gave him and his tiny party a national platform. In mid-2003, Beddoes responded to rising interest among [[Fijians|indigenous]] and [[Indians in Fiji|Indo-]] Fijians by announcing that membership of his party, which had been confined to [[General electors|minority groups]] like Europeans, Chinese, and [[Banaba Island|Banaban Islanders]], would now be open to all races, and that the party would contest all 71 seats in the House of Representatives in the next [[Fijian general election, 2006|parliamentary election]], scheduled for 2006.
Beddoes criticised the ethnic faultlines that characterise Fijian politics; communal voting was a factor in this, he said on 28 August 2005, but could be mitigated if only voters would judge a candidate according to his or her personal merits, rather than on the basis of whether the candidate's political party was [[Fijians|indigenous]]-led or [[Indians in Fiji|Indo-Fijian]]-led. He also called for changes to the electoral system, under which almost two-thirds of the House of Representatives are elected from [[communal constituencies]], whose electors are registered members of a particular ethnic group.
== Second term as Leader of the Opposition == Beddoes retained his constituency, with a slightly reduced majority, in the [[Fijian general election, 2006|parliamentary election]] held on 6–13 May 2006, and was appointed Leader of the Opposition for the second time on 3 June <small>([http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO0606/S00088.htm source]).</small> His second appointment came after weeks of disputes with his erstwhile ally, Mahendra Chaudhry, who had insisted that the position should be his, despite the decision of the Labour Party to enter a [[grand coalition]] with the [[Soqosoqo Duavata ni Lewenivanua]] Party (SDL). After obtaining legal advice, [[President of Fiji|President]] [[Ratu]] [[Josefa Iloilo]] appointed Beddoes.
As of 19 September, Beddoes was still performing his duties only on a part-time basis, [[Fiji Television]] reported. To assume the position full-time, he would be [[1997 Constitution of Fiji|constitutionally]] required to divest himself of his private business interests.
== Campaign against controversial bill == Throughout much of 2005, Beddoes was at the forefront of a public campaign against the government's controversial [[Reconciliation, Tolerance, and Unity Bill]], which provided for the establishment of a Commission empowered to compensate victims and pardon perpetrators of the [[2000 Fijian coup d'état|coup d'état]] which deposed the [[People's Coalition (Fiji)|People's Coalition]] government in May 2000. Beddoes travelled throughout Fiji, speaking against the bill, which was, he claimed, nothing other than a legal mechanism for releasing from prison persons convicted of involvement in the coup, who were supporters of or in some way linked to the present government. The bill was temporarily shelved during the election and its aftermath. An amended version was pending, but the [[2006 Fijian coup d'état|military coup]] of 5 December 2006 put an end to it.
== 2006 coup d'état == {{Main|2006 Fijian coup d'état}}
Long considered an ally of the [[Republic of Fiji Military Forces]] in their long-running dispute with the Qarase government, Beddoes began criticising the Military towards the end of 2006, as tensions escalated to unprecedented levels. On 20 October, [[Fiji Television]] quoted him as calling for an end to the Military's attempts to intimidate the government. On the other hand, he called on the government on 28 November to placate the Military by dropping investigations into insubordination on the part of the Commander, [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] [[Frank Bainimarama]]. ''"All it is doing is putting a red rag in front of a bull and the bull has 4,000 guns,"'' he told Australia's [[ABC Radio National|ABC Radio]]. On 1 December, as it became apparent that a coup was imminent, he branded the Military a bunch of bullies, and issued a strong warning to persons who might be considering accepting office in an interim government, saying that they would be taken to task when the storm had passed. On 4 December, Beddoes called on Fijians to rally in support of the rule of law.
Beddoes condemned the coup of 5 December, and spoke out strongly against what he saw as violations of constitutional and human rights.
Beddoes welcomed the decision of the Military to restore [[Ratu]] [[Josefa Iloilo]] to the [[President of Fiji|Presidency]] on 4 January 2007, but condemned the appointment of Bainimarama as interim [[Prime Minister of Fiji|Prime Minister]] on 5 January and criticised the President's endorsement of the coup, the [[Fiji Times]] reported. He expressed disappointment when his deputy, [[Bernadette Ganilau|Bernadette Rounds-Ganilau]], accepted office in Bainimarama's interim government, and asked her to resign from the UPP. He was particularly disappointed, he said, that Ganilau's decision came less than twenty-four hours after he had been visited by soldiers conveying a message from [[Land Force Commander (Fiji)|Land Force Commander]] [[Pita Driti]] threatening him to stop speaking against the Military. On 10 January, he accused the [[Fiji Labour Party]], some of whose leading figures, were included in the interim government, of having been privy to the coup plot.[http://www.fijivillage.com/artman/publish/article_34995.shtml]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
== Social views == On 27 August 2005, Beddoes spoke out against calls by some for the closure of loopholes in the [[Penal Code]] which had allowed the release of two men, one a Fijian citizen and the other a foreigner, who had been sentenced to a prison term on 5 April for homosexual acts. This sentence was overturned on 26 August by Justice [[Gerald Winter (judge)|Gerald Winter]], who said that the Penal Code was not applicable to what adults did in private.
The same day, Beddoes condemned [[Senate of Fiji|Senator]] [[Mitieli Bulanauca]] for speaking against homosexuality and attacking Justice Winter in the Senate. ''"Senator Bulanauca is among a very small percentage of misfits and clowns who live off the lies they try to spin to try and intimidate others, while sheltering behind [[parliamentary privilege]],"'' Beddoes said. ''"These expressions of hate come from a man who claims he is a Christian and quotes endlessly from the Bible."''
== Retirement == On 20 January 2007, Beddoes announced that he would retire from the presidency of the UPP at the Annual General Meeting of his party, on 31 March.
After the winding up of the UPP in January 2013, Beddoes announced that he would join the new [[Social Democratic Liberal Party]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=73723 |title=Fiji's Beddoes to join budding SDL |publisher=Radio New Zealand International |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Museum of American Finance | image = Museum of American Finance at William and Wall Streets in lower Manhattan by Alan Barnett.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Looking northeast from [[Wall Street]] toward the museum. | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|23|N|74|00|33|W|type:landmark_region:US-NY|display=inline,title}} | established = 1988 (as the '''Museum of American Financial History''') | location = [[48 Wall Street]]
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | type = [[Finance]] museum; [[Smithsonian Institution]] affiliate | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = {{URL|http://www.moaf.org}} }} The '''Museum of American Finance''' is the [[United States]]'s only independent [[Museum|public museum]] dedicated to preserving, exhibiting and teaching about American finance and financial [[history]]. Located in the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]] it is an [[affiliated institution|affiliate]] of the [[Smithsonian Institution]].{{cite web | url=https://affiliations.si.edu/AffilDirectory.Asp?MenuID=11#M | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060625060409/http://affiliations.si.edu/AffilDirectory.Asp?MenuID=11#M | dead-url=yes | archive-date=25 June 2006 | title=Smithsonian Affiliates: M | work=[https://affiliations.si.edu/ Smithonian Affiliations] | publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]] | accessdate=2 September 2014 }} It is a tax-exempt 501(c) 3 organization chartered by the [[New York State Department of Education|Board of Regents of the New York State Department of Education]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} With education at the core of its mission, it is an active national-level advocate on behalf of [[financial literacy]]. The museum was founded in 1988 as the [[Museum of American Financial History]] but was renamed the Museum of American Finance in 2005.{{cite web| url=http://www.moaf.org/about/history | title=History | publisher=Museum of American Finance | accessdate=2 September 2014 }} Until December 2006, it was located at [[26 Broadway]]. On January 11, 2008, the Museum opened in a new location at [[48 Wall Street]],{{cite news| title=Where the Capitalism is (Always on Display) | newspaper=[[New York Times]] | date=February 2, 2008 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/02/arts/design/02muse.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=where%20the%20capitalism%20is%20always%20on%20display&st=cse&oref=slogin }} the former headquarters of [[Bank of New York|The Bank of New York]].Press release (November 28, 2005). "Museum of American Finance Moving to Wall Street – 30,000 Sq. Ft. Museum Will Be Financial District Visitors Center" (PDF format). Museum of American Finance. Archived from the original on October 11, 2011. Retrieved January 26, 2007. ==Financial education== In 2010, the Museum founded its Center for Financial Education, which offers classroom programs for students in grades [[kindergarten]] through masters of business administration ([[MBA]]) in addition to its tour programs.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} In 2011, it launched the Museum Finance Academy (MFA), an eight-week after school personal finance program open to high school juniors and seniors. In 2011–2013, the Museum partnered with [[Junior Achievement]] to offer its "Finance Park" program within the Center for Financial Education.{{cite web|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/video?id=7872097|title=ABC7 Eyewitness News – WABC-TV New York|work=ABC7 New York|accessdate=2 November 2014}} ==Collections and exhibitions== As part of its mission to document US financial history, the Museum actively collects [[documents]] and [[wikt:artifact|artifact]]s related to the [[financial markets]], [[money]] and [[banking]].{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} Its world-class collection includes more than 10,000 [[stocks]], [[bond (finance)|bond]]s, prints, [[engravings]], [[photographs]], [[bank notes]], [[cheque|checks]] and [[books]]. Permanent exhibitions focus on the [[financial markets]], money, banking, [[entrepreneurship]] and [[Alexander Hamilton]]. Recent{{when|date=September 2014}} temporary exhibitions include "[[Barings]] in America: An Interactive Investment Experience" (December 2012 – April 2013),{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-22/the-british-bank-that-forever-altered-the-u-s-economy.html|title=The British Bank That Forever Altered the U.S. Economy|work=BloombergView.com|accessdate=2 November 2014}} "[[Checks and balances|Checks & Balances]]: [[Presidents]] and American Finance" (November 2011 – March 2013),{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204443404577052101244153524?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Checks & Balances – Museum of American Finance – Of Debt and Taxes – By Mark Yost – WSJ|author=Mark Yost|date=14 December 2011|work=WSJ|accessdate=2 November 2014}} "Tracking the Credit Crisis" (ongoing since 2009);[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/22/business/22museum.html?_r=3&hp& “Credit Crisis is a Big Draw for Finance Museum”], The New York Times, August 21, 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/museums/mid-atlantic-offers-a-wealth-of-museum-exhibits/2012/10/03/df73f1f8-097a-11e2-a10c-fa5a255a9258_story.html|title=Mid-Atlantic offers a wealth of museum exhibits|author=Mark Jenkins|date=4 October 2012|work=Washington Post}} "[[Alexander Hamilton]]: Lineage and Legacy" (April 2011 – March 2012);{{cite web|url=http://www.thedeal.com/video/regulation/meet-alexander-hamilton-founde.php|title=Meet Alexander Hamilton, founder of U.S. financial system|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2014}} "Scandal! Financial Crime Chicanery and Corruption That Rocked America" (2010–11){{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/news/video/story?videoId=79408999&videoChannel=5|title=Wall Street scandals on display|work=Reuters|accessdate=2 November 2014}}[https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2010/07/18/business/20100718-backdrop-ss.html "Of Scoundrels and Scandals”], The New York Times, July 18, 2010 and "[[Women]] of [[Wall Street]]" (2009–10).[http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/04/the-women-of-wall-street/ "Museum Celebrates the Women of Wall Street,”], The New York Times, June 4, 2009. The exhibit "Alexander Hamilton: Indispensable Founder and Visionary" had its grand opening at the Museum of American Finance in New York City on October 29, 2014. Former Secretary of the Treasury [[Timothy Geithner]] cut the ribbon to open the exhibit, which is located in the Hamilton room in the museum. The exhibit was co-curated by John Herzog, Founder of the Museum of American Finance, and Mariana Oller, the Chair of the Alexander Hamilton Awareness Society.This exhibit was created to commemorate the 225th anniversary of Alexander Hamilton becoming the first Secretary of the Treasury that year. The exhibit is currently one of the main attractions of the Museum, and features rare objects associated with [[Alexander Hamilton]] and his financial programs.{{cite web|title=On Exhibition - "Alexander Hamilton: Indispensable Founder and Visionary"|url=http://www.the-aha-society.com/index.php/publications/articles/87-aha-society-articles/175-exhibit-indispensable-founder-visionary|website=www.theAHAsociety.com|accessdate=October 29, 2014}} ==Programs and events== Prominent speakers from across the financial industry participate in the Museum's Financial History and Practices Lecture/Symposia Series, with subject matter ranging from discussions of current financial practices to observations on significant events and individuals in America's financial history. Speakers have included [[John Bogle]], [[Sallie Krawcheck]],{{cite web|url=http://postcards.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2009/10/08/sallie-krawcheck-the-big-job-she-didnt-take/|title=Sallie Krawcheck: the big job she didn't take|work=Fortune|accessdate=2 November 2014}} [[David M. Walker (U.S. Comptroller General)|David Walker]], [[Abby Joseph Cohen]], [[Henry Kaufman]], [[Niall Ferguson]] and [[Neil Barofsky]].{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbanker.com/issues/177_208/former-inspector-general-tarp-neil-barofsky-offers-thoughts-fix-financial-1053907-1.html|title=Big Banks' Hold on Regulators Must Be Broken: Barofsky|author=Brian Browdie|date=26 October 2012|work=American Banker}} Other programs include the Lunch and Learn Series, which features talks, demonstrations and presentations during lunchtime, as well as [[walking tours]] and film screenings. The Museum's annual gala honors an individual with the Whitehead Award for Distinguished Public Service and Financial Leadership, which is named after former [[Deputy Secretary of State]] and co-chair of [[Goldman Sachs]] [[John C. Whitehead]]. Honorees have included [[Paul Volcker]],{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/01/13/usa-economy-volcker-idUSN1236427820090113|title=UPDATE 2-Obama adviser Volcker: this crisis is different|work=Reuters|accessdate=2 November 2014}} [[Pete Peterson]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-11/blackstone-s-peterson-says-debt-threatens-american-dream-at-wall-st-gala.html|title=Blackstone's Peterson Warns About U.S. Debt After Winning Award|author=Patrick Cole|date=11 January 2011|work=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=2 November 2014}} [[William Donaldson]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601088&sid=ahUeqGlxlzdI|title=Obama Adviser Donaldson to Receive John Whitehead Award at Gala|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2014}} [[Felix Rohatyn]]{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-01-10/scene-last-night-rohatyn-john-whitehead-martin-lipton-vernon-jordan.html|title=Scene Last Night: Rohatyn, Whitehead, Martin Lipton|author=Amanda Gordon|date=23 January 2012|work=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=2 November 2014}} and [[William B. Harrison, Jr.|William Harrison]], Jr.[https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/01/09/wall-streets-elite-including-ina-drew-honors-jpmorgans-former-leader/ “Wall Street’s Elite, Including Ina Drew, Honors JPMorgan’s Former Leader”]. The New York Times Deal Book, January 9, 2013. Since 2012, the Museum of American Finance has partnered with the Alexander Hamilton Awareness Society co-hosting several events of the yearly [[CelebrateHAMILTON]] and Happy Birthday Hamilton! programs in July and January. Events included ''"The Essence of Alexander Hamilton's Greatness"'' by AHA Society founder, Rand Scholet,{{cite web|last1=Museum of American Finance|title=Rand Scholet on "The Essence of Alexander Hamilton's Greatness"|url=http://www.moaf.org/events/general/evt_20120712|website=www.MoAF.org|accessdate=July 12, 2012}} Hamilton vs. Jefferson historical interpreters "Debate",{{cite web|last1=Museum of American Finance|title=Hamilton vs. Jefferson Debate Featuring William G. Chrystal|url=http://www.moaf.org/events/general/evt_20130711|website=www.MoAF.org|accessdate=July 11, 2013}} "Conversation with the Curators" with John Herzog, founder of the Museum of American Finance and Mariana Oller, Chair of the Alexander Hamilton Awareness Society on the process of collecting original Hamilton documents and then creating the "Alexander Hamilton: Indispensable Founder and Visionary" exhibit with them,{{cite web|last1=Scholet|first1=Nicole|title=Conversation with the Curators|url=http://www.the-aha-society.com/index.php/publications/articles/87-aha-society-articles/175-exhibit-indispensable-founder-visionary|website=www.theAHAsociety.com|accessdate=9 January 2015}} the "New Discoveries in the life of Alexander Hamilton" Talk by Author and Historian Michael E. Newton,{{cite web|last1=CelebrateHAMILTON|first1=The AHA Society & Museum of American Finance|title=Alexander Hamilton scholar Michael E. Newton presented "New Discoveries in the Life of Alexander Hamilton|url=http://www.moaf.org/events/general/evt_20140714|website=www.MoAF.org|accessdate=July 14, 2014}} and the presentation of his new book "Alexander Hamilton - The Formative Years".{{cite web|last1=Museum of American Finance Events|title=Michael Newton on "Alexander Hamilton: The Formative Years"|url=http://www.moaf.org/events/general/evt_20150710|website=www.moaf.org|accessdate=July 10, 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Newton|first1=Michael E.|title=Alexander Hamilton: The Formative Years|date=July 1, 2015|publisher=Eleftheria Publishing|isbn=0982604033|pages=774|edition=Hardcover|url=http://michaelenewton.com/alexander-hamilton-the-formative-years/}} ==Publications== The Museum also regularly [[publishes]] on subjects pertaining to the history of finance. Its quarterly magazine, ''Financial History'', reaches members in 50 US states and 20 other countries. The magazine publishes [[vetted]] articles by financial historians and [[journalists]] on historically significant events and individuals and other related topics in the world of finance.{{cite web| first=Katie | last=Petito | title=Museum of American Finance: New Name, New Location | url=http://www.dndco.com/images/Museum_1.pdf | publisher=dndco.com }} In 2011, the Museum commemorated the 100th issue of ''Financial History'' with a full-color double edition.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} The Museum also publishes [[books]] and [[Collection catalog|catalog]]s including, most recently, ''The Revolutionary Beginning of the American [[Stock Market]]'', which features many of the documents in the "America's First [[IPO]]" exhibit. ==Intellectual leadership== In 1987, John E. Herzog, then CEO of [[Herzog Heine Geduld, Inc.]], established the Museum in response to the [[stock market crash]] of that year.http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=9871274&privcapId=50258218&previousCapId=3701492&previousTitle=OneLink Corporation{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/25/business/in-a-museum-market-artifacts-and-lots-of-perspective.html?n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes|title=Topics: People: R Rockefeller, John D.|date=25 October 1998|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2014}} He provided the bulk of the institution's early leadership and is now chairman and trustee emeritus.{{cite web|url=http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2012/05/18/477197/256606/en/Museum-of-American-Finance-Founder-John-E-Herzog-Retires-From-Board.html|title=Museum of American Finance Founder John E. Herzog Retires From Board|author=Museum of American Finance|work=GlobeNewswire News Room|accessdate=1 November 2014}} The Museum's intellectual leadership is currently provided by eminent financial historians, including board trustee [[Niall Ferguson]],http://www.smu.edu/TateSeries/LectureSchedule/2012-2013/FergusonNiall {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121118235049/http://www.smu.edu/TateSeries/LectureSchedule/2012-2013/FergusonNiall |date=November 18, 2012 }} Chairman of the Board [[Richard Sylla|Richard E. Sylla]],{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100601006377/en/Dr.-Richard-Sylla-Elected-Chairman-Museum-American|title=Dr. Richard Sylla Elected Chairman of Museum of American Finance|publisher=|accessdate=1 November 2014}} President and CEO David Cowen,Nathaniel Popper, "At Wall Street Museum, Financial Crisis Staged a Takeover," Los Angeles Times (29 October 2010). http://articles.latimes.com/2010/oct/29/business/la-fi-finance-museum-20101029 and ''Financial History'' magazine editorial board member [[Robert E. Wright]].{{cite web|url=http://www.moaf.org/about/people/wright_robert|title=Dr. Robert E. Wright|publisher=|accessdate=1 November 2014}} ==Gallery== Museum of American Finance Main Gallery by Markus Hartel.jpg|Main gallery Museum of American Finance Money Gallery by Elsa Ruiz.JPG|Money gallery Hamilton Room by Elsa Ruiz.jpg|Hamilton Room Information section by Markus Hartel.JPG|Information section ==See also== {{portal|Architecture|Business and economics|History|New York City|Numismatics}} *[[Culture of New York City]] *[[History of New York City]] *[[List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City]] *[[List of museums in New York]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{commons category inline}} *{{official website|http://www.moaf.org}} {{Museums in Manhattan|state=collapsed}} [[Category:1988 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Finance in the United States]] [[Category:History museums in New York City]] [[Category:Museums established in 1988]] [[Category:Museums in Manhattan]] [[Category:Museums of economics]] [[Category:Numismatic museums in the United States]] [[Category:Smithsonian Institution affiliates]] [[Category:Financial District, Manhattan]] [[Category:Financial history of the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox university | name = NUCB Business School | image_name = NUCB_Business_School.svg | motto = ''Frontier Spirit'' | established = 1990 | type = [[Private school#Japan|Private]] [[graduate school|graduate]] [[business school]] | dean = Yayutomi Kitahara | faculty = 40+ | staff = 20 | students = 840
(640 in [[Degree Program]])
(200 in [[Executive Education]]) | city = [[Nagoya]] | state = [[Aichi]] | country = Japan | campus = [[Tokyo]] [[Osaka]] [[Nagoya]] | affiliations = [[AACSB]], [[Association of MBAs|AMBA]] | website = {{URL|http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en}} }} '''NUCB Business School''' is a private [[graduate school|graduate]] [[business school]] in Japan. The school was established in 1990 by the Kurimoto Educational Institution, a internationally accredited and legally incorporated private educational institution. The school offers an [[Executive Master of Business Administration|EMBA]] program, [[MBA]] program, [[Master of Science|M.Sc.]] programs, [[Master of Management|MIM]] program, and [[executive education]] programs. == Overview == === Mission === The School’s mission is to educate innovative and ethical leaders who possess a ʻFrontier Spiritʼ and to create knowledge that advances business and society. Our students will have the ability to bridge the gap between New Asia and the rest of the world.{{cite web|url=http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en/about.html|title=Mission Statement - NUCB Business School|publisher=}} === History === NUCB Business School was established in 1990 and launched graduate-level degree programs to develop skilled and innovative business managers. In 2003 the School launched the first EMBA program in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en/history.html|title=History and Milestones - NUCB Business School|publisher=}} * 1990 - NUCB Business School founded to provide graduate-level management education * 2000 - One-year evening [[MBA]] program in Information Technology Management launched * 2003 - Two-year [[Executive MBA]] launched * 2004 - Two-year [[M.Sc.]] in Taxation launched * 2005 - Tokyo campus opened * 2005 - Two-year MIM (English-track) launched * 2005 - Center for Strategic Management established * 2006 - The School becomes the second institution in Japan to be accredited by [[AACSB]] International * 2007 - Osaka Campus opened * 2009 - The School becomes the first institution in Japan to be accreditation by the [[Association of MBAs]] (AMBA) * 2009 - Membership of [[Association of Asia-Pacific Business School]] (AAPBS) * 2011 - Non-degree executive education launched * 2011 - Membership of [[Principle for Responsible Management Education]] (PRME) * 2011 - Asia Pacific Case Center established * 2012 - Membership of [[Executive MBA Council]] (EMBAC) * 2013 - International [[Advisory board|Advisory Board]] established * 2013 - Two-year [[MBA]] in Entrepreneurship launched * 2015 - Nagoya Marunouchi Campus opened * 2015 - Center for Family Business established * 2017 - Healthcare MBA track established * 2018 - Center for [[Case Method]] established * 2018 - Hosted the [[Case Method]] Seminar by [[Harvard Business Publishing]] === International Accreditation === * [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business|AACSB]]（Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business） * [[Association of MBAs|AMBA]]（Association of MBAs） === International Memberships === * AAPBS - Association of Asia-Pacific Business Schools *[[European Foundation for Management Development|EFMD]] - European Foundation for Management Development * EMBAC - [[Executive MBA Council]] * PRME - Principles for Responsible Management Education === Local Accreditation === * JIHEE - [[Japan Institution of Higher Education Evaluation]] NUCB Business School offers a [[MEXT]]'s BP Accredited part-time Executive MBA program, a part-time MBA in Innovation and Entrepreneurship, and a part-time MSc in Taxation as well as a full-time and a part-time Masters in Management program. === Rankings === * [[QS World University Rankings|QS]] Ranking 2018{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/mba-rankings/asia-australia-nz/2018|title=World University Rankings - Full Time MBA: Asia, Australia & NZ 2018|date=23 November 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.topmba.com/emba-rankings/asia/2018|title=Executive MBA Rankings - Asia Pacific 2018|date=20 April 2018|publisher=}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-bottom: 10px;" !Program !Category !Japan !Asia !World |- |Executive MBA　 |EMBA |#1 |#14　 |#111 |- |MIM（MBA in English） |Global MBA |#2 |#21 |#151 |} * [[eduniversal]] Ranking 2018{{cite web|url=http://www.eduniversal-survey-mastersranking.com/|title=Eduniversal Masters Ranking 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin-bottom: 10px;" !Program !Category !Japan !Asia !World |- |Executive MBA　 |Executive MBA |#1 |#4 | |- |MBA |MBA in Entrepreneurship |#1 |#1 |#27 |- |MIM（MBA in English） |General Management |#1 |#2 | |- |MSc in Taxation |Taxation |#1 |#1 |#3 |} === Campus === The School expanded into [[Tokyo]] in 2005 and then in [[Osaka]] in 2007. The satellite campus in Tokyo, the Tokyo [[Marunouchi]] Campus is located one minute away from the JR Tokyo Station. The Osaka satellite campus originally occupied space in [[Umeda]] but was later moved to the Grand Front Osaka in Umekita which is also one minute away from the city's major JR train station. Both satellite campuses were chosen for their location in commercial/finance districts for their proximity to major train stations. *[[Nagoya]] Marunouchi *[[Tokyo]] Marunouchi *[[Osaka]] Umekita == Academic Programs == === Degree Education === * [[Executive MBA|EMBA]] - Executive MBA * [[MBA]] - Master of Business Administration * [[Master of Management|MIM]] - Master in Management (English) * [[MSc]] - Master of Science in Taxation === Executive Education === * MBA Essentials * PreMBA (Certificate) ===Exchange Program=== The School offers an English-taught [[Student exchange program|exchange program]] and [[double degree]] program. Involving over fifty different business courses from full-time faculty as well as guest professors from its partner schools, the program utilizes the case method to facilitate the exchange of diverse student backgrounds and perspectives. Exchange students can enroll for as short as two months following the four-term academic year schedule. This is designed to allow students on an exchange program to not only study but travel across Japan for a well-rounded study abroad experience.The [[double degree]] program requires that students spend one year at the School and one year at one of their 100+ partner schools. ===Exchange and Double Degree Partners=== As of 2018, the School had standing academic and student exchange agreements with 113 global partner institutions for post-graduate faculty exchange and student exchange. Schools with the asterisk (*) denote listed double degree partners.[http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en/international/ NUCB Business School Homepage 2018] {| style="width:100%;" |- | style="vertical-align:top;" width=""| *{{FRA}} **[[Montpellier Business School]] **[[Toulouse Business School]] **[[KEDGE Business School]] **[[NEOMA Business School]]* **[[IESEG School of Management]] **[[Audencia Nantes School of Management]]* **[[ICN Business School]]* **[[EMLYON Business School]] **[[EDHEC Business School]]* **[[Burgundy School of Business]] **[[Sciences Po Lille]] **[[ESC Rennes School of Business]]* University of Management]] |} == Research Center == * Center for Entrepreneurship * Center for Family business * Center for Case method * Center for Strategic management ==Institutional Partners== NUCB Business School has international exchanges with 113 partner business schools from 51 countries around the world including [[University of Alberta]] in Canada, [[Audencia Business School]] in France and [[Sasin Graduate Institute of Business Administration of Chulalongkorn University]] in Thailand. The Graduate School also facilitates a study abroad program for executive-level students at [[Harvard Business School]], [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] and [[IMD Business School]].{{cite web|url=http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en/international/|title=Global Partners - NUCB Business School|last=|first=|date=July 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == Official Site == * [http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/en/ NUCB Business School - EN] * [http://mba.nucba.ac.jp/ NUCB Business School - JP] * [https://mba.reviews/MBA/mba-program-nucb-business-school/ NUCB Business School MBA Program - Student and Alumni Reviews] [[Category:Business schools]] [[Category:Postgraduate schools]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium - NCOIC | logo = [[Image:NCOIC logo.jpg|center|205px|NCOIC Logo]] | type = Non-Profit | foundation = 2004 | key_people =Harry D. Raduege, <small>Chief Executive Officer</small> | industry = [[Telecommunications]] | homepage = https://www.ncoic.org }} The '''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium''' (NCOIC) is an international not-for-profit, chartered in the United States, whose goal is to facilitate the adoption of [[cross-domain interoperability]] standards.<ref>Kenyon, H. [http://washingtontechnology.com/articles/2010/09/30/interoperability-efforts-bear-fruit.aspx "NCOIC's efforts toward product interoperability are showing promise"], ''Washington Technology'', 2010</ref> Formed in September 2004, the organization is composed of more than 50 members and advisors representing business, government organizations and academic institutions in 12 countries.<ref>ASDNews, [http://www.asdnews.com/news-1619/Network_Centric_Operations_Industry_Consortium_-NCOIC-_Launch.htm "Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium -NCOIC- Launch"], ''Aerospace & Defense News'', 2004</ref>
NCO is the application of the fundamental tenets of network-centric warfare to aspects of national security, especially industry support for the missions of both the [[United States Department of Defense]] and the [[Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS). NCOIC does not only subscribe to the military use of this theory, but also works to apply NCO and interoperability across nations and industries, including emergency response, health care, [[aerospace]], [[information technology]] cyber security & [[cloud computing]], energy and financial services.
NCOIC’s technical teams have developed resources to further the use of network-centric systems and interoperability in both the public and private sectors. These resources – including processes, tools, frameworks, patterns, principles and databases—are available free of charge on the NCOIC website. They are aimed at helping an organization lower engineering costs, speed program implementation, increase capability and reduce risk. The consortium also provides training and services such as interoperability demonstrations, acquisition strategies, evaluations and verification.
NCOIC focuses on four interdependent areas in identifying solutions that will enable cross-domain interoperability: business, culture, governance and technical. The interaction, influence and impact of factors—such as financial objectives, business goals, laws and regulations, and cultural considerations – are all taken into account when planning and/or implementing technology change.
==Key Technical Resources==
''Systems, Capabilities, Operations, Programs, & Enterprises (SCOPE) Model'' • The SCOPE interoperability assessment model is designed to characterize interoperability-relevant aspects or capabilities of a system or set of systems over a network in terms of a set of dimensions and values along those dimensions.<ref>Richard Creps, Et Al. [https://www.ncoic.org/images/technology/SCOPE_MODEL_VER1.0.pdf "SCOPE"], ''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium (NCOIC)'', 2008</ref>
''NCOIC Interoperability Framework (NIF)'' • The NIF is a development framework that helps system architects and system engineers to embed interoperability elements throughout the life cycle of programs, beginning with requirements. Whenever possible, those resources are based upon standards.<ref>Mark Bowler. [https://www.ncoic.org/technology/educational-resources/nif-and-net-centric-pattern-overview "NIF"], ''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium (NCOIC)'', 2008</ref> ''
Net Centric Patterns'' • NCOIC Net Centric Patterns contain prescriptive recommendations on approaches and standards in specific interoperability domains.<ref>Walter Legrand. [https://www.ncoic.org/technology/technical-resources/net-centric-patterns "Netcentric Patterns"], ''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium (NCOIC)'', 2010</ref>
''Network Centric Analysis Tool (NCAT)'' • NCAT is a collaborative, web-enabled questionnaire-based tool developed to assist NCOIC teams and member companies to enhance the likelihood and reduce the time and effort of member companies developing interoperable systems consistent with customers’ policies and guidelines, reference models and architectures. It is also available in an excel format. <ref>NCOIC. [https://www.ncoic.org/technology/educational-resources/ncat-overview "NCAT"], ''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium (NCOIC)'', 2010</ref>
''NCOIC QuadTrangle'' • The QuadTrangle™ developed by the Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium shows the four, interdependent areas that must be considered when developing a reliable and trusted interoperable environment: business, culture, governance and technical. <ref>NCOIC. [https://www.ncoic.org/about-us/ncoic-difference/ncoic-quadtrangle "NCOIC QuadTrangle"], ''Network Centric Operations Industry Consortium (NCOIC)'', 2016</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} {{Infobox Chinese-language singer and actor | name = Race Wong | gender = female | image = | image_size = | landscape = | alt = | caption = | background = actor_or_actress | tradchinesename = 黃婉伶 | simpchinesename = 黄婉伶 | pinyinchinesename = Huáng wǎn líng | jyutpingchinesename = wong4 jyun2 ling4 | origin = {{MAS}} | birth_name= Wong Yuen Pui ({{zh|t=黃婉佩|s=黄婉佩|p=Huáng wǎn pèi}}) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1982|09|07}} | birth_place = [[Kuala Lumpur]], {{MAS}} | death_date = | death_place = | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | residence = [[Singapore]] | education = | alma mater = [[University of Newcastle (Australia)|University of Newcastle]], [[Australia]] | nationality = [[Singaporean]] | occupation = Singer, actress | years_active = 2002–2009 | genre = [[Cantopop]] | voicetype = | label = | agentcompany = | yearsactive = | associatedact = [[2R (group)|2R]] | spouse = {{marriage|Chan Ching Kai|August 26, 2004|2009|reason=div}}
{{marriage|David Loh|November 25, 2016}} | partner = [[Jacky Heung]] (2009–2012) | children = Cara Loh (daughter) | parents = | siblings = [[Rosanne Wong]] (sister) | relatives = | instrument = | website = {{Facebook|Race-Wong-191796151824|Race Wong}} }} '''Race Wong''' is a Singaporean actress, singer and businesswoman. She was one of the former Hong Kong [[cantopop]] duo singer group [[2R (group)|2R]] alongside with her elder sister [[Rosanne Wong]]. ==Professional background== Born in Malaysia, raised in Singapore, she pursued her career in the entertainment industry in Hong Kong with her sister [[Rosanne Wong]] which won her various awards for her singing career as the [[cantopop]] group [[2R (group)|2R]], including Most Promising Newcomer and Most Popular Group Award in the Annual Top 10 Song of the Year Awards (2003), [[Metro Broadcast Corporation|Metro Broadcasting Music awards]] (2004), [[TVB Anniversary Awards|TVB Top 10 Songs of the Year]] (2004) and Hong Kong Commercial Radio Music Awards’ (2003). Race Wong became a spotlight when she was chosen to star alongside [[Stephen Chow]] in his famous annual San Miguel TV advertisement. Following that, she rose to fame for her leading role in a TVB youth series ''[[Hearts of Fencing]]''. Which jumpstarted both her singing and acting career. Race Wong hoped to focus her acting on roles beyond her youthful and sweet appearance. Her outstanding performance in her first leading role in movie Abnormal Beauty [[Ab-normal Beauty|Abnormal Beauty]] won her a nomination for the Best New Actor in the [[Hong Kong Film Award|24th Annual Hong Kong Film Awards]] (2005) and the 42nd [[Golden Horse Film Festival and Awards|Golden Horse Film Awards]]' (2005) in Taiwan. Race Wong continued to experiment with different roles both on-screen and off-screen. In 2006, together with her sister [[Rosanne Wong]], they took on groundbreaking leading roles in a musical adaption of [[The Smiling, Proud Wanderer#Stage productions|The Smiling Proud Wanderer]] stage performance by the Hong Kong Dance Company (2006) where Rosanne famously shaved bald for the role. The musical enjoyed a success which brought them to perform in Shanghai the following year. Later in 2008, Race Wong's starring role as a pregnant new immigrant from China was a break away from her usual youthful image in the movie [[True Women for Sale]] which earned her a nomination for Best Supporting Actress in the 28th Hong Kong Film Awards (2009). Race is one of the very rare few Singaporeans to have been nominated in the Hong Kong Film Awards. In 2010, Race Wong decided to step out of the limelight for a break. She took on a Masters of Business course to further her education and graduated with a Masters of Business majoring in Marketing from the [[University of Newcastle (Australia)|University of Newcastle]] (Australia) in 2013. Concurrently in 2011, she made an unexpected career change into finance, taking on the role of Marketing Manager at [[Maybank Kim Eng|Maybank Kim Eng Securities]] (Hong Kong). She was licensed with the [[Securities and Futures Commission]] to conduct equities trading. The year she turned 30, Race Wong made a surprising move to relocate back to Singapore where her family is based. Together with her younger sister Rhonda Wong, she set up Anthill Realtors Pte. Ltd. in 2013 a real estate agency licensed with CEA. She then co-founded Ohmyhome Pte Ltd in 2015, a tech company focused on connecting buyers to sellers, landlords to tenants in real estate. When asked about her career move, Race said that she wanted to focus her attention on something that will provide more value to people, something on the opposite spectrum of her celebrity lifestyle. She speaks fluent Cantonese, Mandarin, and English. ==Discography== *See [[2R (group)#Discography|Discography of 2R]] ==Album== *''2006 2R 新歌+精選 (CD+DVD)/ The Best of 2R (CD+DVD) *''2005 2R Revolution *''2004 United R (1st Issue special edition Bonus VCD)/ *''United R (2nd Version) *''2003 Two of Us (3rd Version) *''Two of Us (2nd Version) *''Two of Us (AVEP) ==Product Spokesperson== *''2008 Modern Beauty *''2006 Microworks Technology *''2005 Citicall *''2004 Biotherm *''2004 SAFA Mp3 *''2004 2R Online *''2004 花花瘦身茶/ Fruity Flower Tea *''2003 Polaroid & Cool-iCam ==Advertisements/Commercials==
