Tech]] *[[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] }} | alma_mater = {{flat list| *[[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur|IIT-Kanpur]] *[[Indian Institute of Management Bangalore|IIM-Bangalore]] }} | occupation = {{flat list| *[[Entrepreneurship|Entrepreneur]] *[[Author]] }} | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = [[Author]] of Platform Revolution, [[CEO]] of Platformation Labs | notable_works = {{flat list | *''Platform Scale'' *''Platform Revolution'' }} | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = <!-- Net worth should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | height = <!-- {{height|m=}} --> | weight = <!-- {{convert|weight in kg|kg|lb}} --> | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | criminal_charge = <!-- Criminality parameters should be supported with citations from reliable sources --> | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = <!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = {{URL|http://platformthinkinglabs.com/}} | footnotes = }}
'''Sangeet Paul Choudary''' is an [[India]]n entrepreneur, advisor, and business author. He is best known for his work on [[two-sided market|platform economics]] and network effects. He is the co-author of the book ''Platform Revolution: How Networked Markets Are Transforming the Economy and How to Make Them Work for You.''<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://books.wwnorton.com/books/detail.aspx?id=4294989879|title=Platform Revolution {{!}} W. W. Norton & Company|website=books.wwnorton.com|access-date=2017-04-01}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/innovations/wp/2016/03/31/heres-the-advantage-that-keeps-silicon-valley-ahead-of-the-world/|title=Here’s the advantage that keeps Silicon Valley ahead of the world|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-04-01}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/why-facebooks-imitators-failed-1463610874|title=Why Facebook’s Imitators Failed|last=Philips|first=Jeremy G.|date=2016-05-18|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-04-01|issn=0099-9660|url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/tech-savvy-is-it-time-to-build-your-own-platform/|title=Is It Time to Build Your Own Platform?|work=MIT Sloan Management Review|access-date=2017-04-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
Choudary's work on platform economics was selected as one of the top 10 management ideas globally by the Harvard Business Review, and included in the collection ''HBR’s 10 Must Reads 2017.''<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://hbr.org/product/hbrs-10-must-reads-2017-the-definitive-management-ideas-of-the-year-from-harvard-business-review/10064-PBK-ENG|title=HBR's 10 Must Reads 2017: The Definitive Management Ideas of the Year from Harvard Business Review (with bonus article)|website=hbr.org|access-date=2017-04-01}}</ref>
For his contributions to the field of platform economics, Choudary was named a [[Young Global Leader]] by the World Economic Forum in 2017.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://widgets.weforum.org/ygl-2017/|title=Young Global Leaders class of 2017|website=widgets.weforum.org|language=en|access-date=2017-03-15}}</ref>
==Career== Choudary is the author of several books, including ''Platform Revolution: How Networked Markets Are Transforming the Economy and How to Make Them Work for You.''<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> ''Platform Revolution'' was ranked an international best-seller by 800CEOREAD<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://inthebooks.800ceoread.com/bestsellers/articles/may-2016-business-book-bestsellers|title=May 2016 Business Book Bestsellers|access-date=2017-09-24|language=en}}</ref> and a must-read business book for 2016 by Forbes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidburkus/2016/01/10/16-must-read-business-books-for-2016/#5cce39c14eca|title=16 Must-Read Business Books For 2016|last=Burkus|first=David|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en}}</ref> In 2015, Choudary wrote the book ''Platform Scale: How an emerging business model helps startups build large empires with minimum investment.''<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/the-11-core-skills-needed-to-be-a-high-impact-entrepreneur-according-to-the-chief-scientist-2015-10|title=The 11 core skills needed to be a high-impact entrepreneur, according to the chief scientist|last=Pash|first=Chris|date=2015-10-30|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.techinasia.com/book-tells-you-how-to-build-the-next-uber-for-x|title=Tech in Asia - Connecting Asia's startup ecosystem|website=www.techinasia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-06}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/education/nilekani-urges-iimb-graduates-to-embrace-technology-move-away-from-pipe-models/article8393678.ece|title=Nilekani urges IIM-B graduates to embrace technology, move away from ‘pipe’ models|last=Bureau|first=Our|date=2016-03-24|work=The Hindu Business Line|access-date=2017-04-06|language=en}}</ref>
Choudary is appointed as an external expert on several Fortune 500 advisory boards, including the [[ING Group|ING Bank]]'s Global Innovation Council.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ing.com/Newsroom/All-news/Learning-from-the-best.htm|title=Learning from the best|last=ING.com|date=2017-07-18|work=ING.com|access-date=2017-07-18|language=en}}</ref> He is also appointed to the World Economic Forum's Global Future Council on Platforms and Systems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/communities/the-future-of-platforms-and-systems|title=The Future of Platforms and Systems|website=World Economic Forum|access-date=2017-05-06}}</ref> He has also been retained as an industry thought leader by technology brands including Microsoft,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.microsoft.com/es-es/2017/01/31/microsoft-presenta-su-propuesta-de-plataforma-para-dar-soporte-a-la-transformacion-digital/#sm.0000mpfg5efbbcz0wvq2cb5citht4#MREolXuI6T1xw9Bt.97|title=Microsoft presenta su propuesta de plataforma para dar soporte a la transformación digital - Centro de noticias|date=2017-01-31|work=Centro de noticias|access-date=2017-04-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.datagora.es/2017/02/01/dynamics-365-plataforma-de-microsoft-para-la-transformacion-digital/|title=Dynamics 365, plataforma de Microsoft para la transformación digital {{!}} Datagora|last=datagora|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://marketechforum.com/articulo/evento-transformacion-empresarial-con-dynamics-365-de-microsoft/|title=Transformación empresarial con Microsoft Dynamics 365 {{!}} MarTech Forum|work=MarTech Forum {{!}} Foro de Marketing Digital|access-date=2017-04-24|language=es-ES}}</ref> Huawei<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huawei.com/en/press-events/events/mwc/2017/digital-transformation-sharing/operations-transformation|title=Operations Transformation Sharing - Huawei at MWC2017|website=huawei|access-date=2018-07-24}}</ref> and AT&T.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thesummit.att.com/speakers/|title=Speakers - The Summit {{!}} An AT&T Experience|work=The Summit {{!}} An AT&T Experience|access-date=2017-09-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
Choudary has addressed high-level political delegations at various UN bodies, including the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO)<ref name=":21">{{Cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/edocs/mdocs/mdocs/en/wipo_gdcm_del_18/wipo_gdcm_del_18_inf_1_prov.pdf|title=World Intellectual Property Organization|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and the International Labor Organization (ILO)<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/future-of-work/news/WCMS_583490/lang--en/index.htm|title=High-level seminar on the "Sharing Economy and its Social Challenges"|date=2017-10-16|access-date=2017-11-10|language=en}}</ref> as well as leading industry summits, including the Australian Financial Review Summit.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/brand/business-summit/a-decade-after-the-gfc-business-must-grasp-the-opportunity-of-growth-20171206-gzzueg|title=How business can beat the disruptors|date=2017-12-06|work=Financial Review|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":18">{{Cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/brand/business-summit/sangeet-choudary-on-amazons-wakeup-call-for-business-20180305-h0x1yq|title=Sangeet Choudary on Amazon's wake-up call for business|date=2018-03-06|work=Financial Review|access-date=2018-03-07|language=en-US}}</ref> Choudary addressed the [[G20 summit|G20 Summit]] in Brisbane in November 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalbrisbane.com.au/News/join-world-leading-digital-thinkers-at-brisbane-global-cafe|title=Join the world’s leading digital thinkers {{!}} Digital Brisbane|website=www.digitalbrisbane.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref><ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessacumen.biz/index.php/14-news/business-travel-events/747-great-minds-attracted-to-g20-brisbane-global-cafe.html|title=Great minds attracted to G20 Brisbane Global Cafe|last=Sullivan|first=Mike|website=www.businessacumen.biz|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-04-24}}</ref> and is a frequent speaker at the events of the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/Media/AMNC16/AMNC16_Programme.pdf|title=World Economic Forum - Annual Meeting of the New Champions Meeting Schedule|last=Agenda|first=Global|date=2016-06-26|website=World Economic Forum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He also frequently addresses the board meetings of Fortune 500 firms, like ANZ Bank.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bluenotes.anz.com/posts/2018/07/are-platforms-the-new-bank-branches-|title=Are platforms the new bank branches?|access-date=2018-08-12}}</ref>
Choudary co-authored the article "Pipelines, Platforms, and the New Rules of Strategy" in the April 2016 edition of the ''[[Harvard Business Review]]''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://hbr.org/2016/04/pipelines-platforms-and-the-new-rules-of-strategy|title=Pipelines, Platforms, and the New Rules of Strategy|work=Harvard Business Review|access-date=2017-04-01}}</ref> This article was subsequently selected as one of the top 10 management ideas for the year 2017''.''<ref name=":1" /> In 2017, Choudary was also selected as one of the 50 thinkers included in the compilation Dear CEO by Thinkers50.<ref name=":12" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisacohn/2017/09/25/thinkers50-create-the-oscars-of-management-thinking/#510755193237|title=Thinkers50 Create The Oscars Of Management Thinking|last=Cohn|first=Alisa|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en}}</ref>
Choudary is an [[Entrepreneur in Residence|Entrepreneur-in-Residence]] at the [[INSEAD|INSEAD Business School]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://centres.insead.edu/entrepreneurship/entrepreneurs-in-residence/singapore.cfm|title=INSEAD Centre for Entrepreneurship|website=centres.insead.edu|access-date=2017-04-30}}</ref> and the co-chair of the MIT Platform Strategy Summit at the [[MIT Media Lab]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://alisterpaine.com/2015/08/05/heres-what-you-missed-at-mits-2nd-annual-platform-strategy-summit/|title=Here’s What You Missed at MIT’s 3rd Annual Platform Strategy Summit|last=Alister & Paine|date=2015-08-05|website=Alister & Paine|access-date=2017-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sloanreview.mit.edu/article/platform-sprawl-leaves-no-industry-behind/|title=Platform Sprawl Leaves No Industry Behind|work=MIT Sloan Management Review|access-date=2017-07-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevebanker/2016/07/28/the-rise-of-the-platform-enterprise/#268574f57313|title=The Rise Of The Platform Enterprise|last=Banker|first=Steve|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-10-21|language=en}}</ref> He is a research fellow at the Centre for Global Enterprise, a New York - based think tank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thecge.net/about/our-leadership/|title=People {{!}} My CMS|website=thecge.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-05}}</ref>
Choudary is an alumnus of the [[Indian Institutes of Technology|Indian Institute of Technology]] (IIT) Kanpur and the [[Indian Institutes of Management|Indian Institute of Management]] (IIM) Bangalore.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://qz.com/262730/why-iits-produce-more-entrepreneurs-than-ivy-league-institutions-like-harvard-or-yale/|title=Why India’s best tech schools produce more entrepreneurs than the Ivy League|work=Quartz|access-date=2017-04-30|language=en-US}}</ref> At the 2016 annual convocation at his alma mater, IIM Bangalore, Choudary received special mention during the convocation speech by chief guest [[Nandan Nilekani]], for his work on platform models.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/education/nilekani-urges-iimb-graduates-to-embrace-technology-move-away-from-pipe-models/article8393678.ece|title=Nilekani urges IIM-B graduates to embrace technology, move away from ‘pipe’ models|last=Bureau|first=Our|date=2016-03-24|work=The Hindu Business Line|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/in-other-news/250316/make-the-best-out-of-shifting-business-trends-nandan-nilekani.html|title=Make the best out of shifting business trends: Nandan Nilekani|date=2016-03-25|work=deccanchronicle.com/|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.economictimes.indiatimes.com/et-commentary/age-of-disruption-those-embracing-change-will-not-only-survive-but-thrive/|title=Age of disruption: Those embracing change will not only survive but thrive|work=Economic Times Blog|access-date=2018-01-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Honors and awards==
* 2017: Selected as a Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://widgets.weforum.org/ygl-2017/|title=Young Global Leaders class of 2017|website=widgets.weforum.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-17}}</ref> *2017: Selected among the top 10 management ideas for the year by Harvard Business Review''.''<ref name=":1" /> * 2016: Ranked among the top 30 management thinkers globally most likely to shape the future of how organizations are managed and led, by Thinkers50 Radar.<ref name=":15">{{cite web|url=http://thinkers50.com/wp-content/uploads/T50-RADAR-2016-PRESSRELEASE-Jan-29-2016.pdf|title=The Thinkers50 Radar 2016|work=Thinkers 50|accessdate=29 January 2016}}</ref> * 2015: Ranked among the top 50 business thinkers of Indian origin, by Thinkers50. Youngest ever to be ranked on this list.<ref name=":14">{{cite web|url=http://businesswireindia.com/news/news-details/50-indian-management-thinkers-who-had-impact-theory-practice-management-2015-thinkers-include-corporate-leaders-dons-from-harvard-kellogg-iims-other-national-international-institutions/46748|title=Business Wire India|work=Thinkers 50|accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref>
==Ideas and theories== Choudary is best known for his work on the transition of business models from pipelines to platforms. He first proposed this idea in a 2013 article for [[Wired (magazine)|WIRED]] magazine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/insights/2013/10/why-business-models-fail-pipes-vs-platforms/|title=Why Business Models Fail: Pipes vs. Platforms|last=Choudary|first=Sangeet Paul|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> The idea, gained widespread adoption<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":18" /> after his 2016 article on this topic was selected by Harvard Business Review among its top 10 ideas of the year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hbr.org/2016/04/pipelines-platforms-and-the-new-rules-of-strategy|title=Pipelines, Platforms, and the New Rules of Strategy|date=2016-04-01|work=Harvard Business Review|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> Choudary is also credited with proposing the idea of the core interaction as the central focus of value creation on platform business models, presented in his books Platform Scale and Platform Revolution.<ref name=":3" /> Choudary's work on the transformation of incumbent businesses to platform business models has been widely quoted in media.<ref name=":19">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alfresco/2016/11/29/the-platform-business-model-why-it-works-and-how-to-get-there-an-interview-with-sangeet-paul-choudary/#19a067e717c3|title=AlfrescoVoice: The Platform Business Model: Why It Works And How to Get There: An Interview With Sangeet Paul Choudary|last=Newton|first=John|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-13|language=en}}</ref> His recent work explains the importance of platform economics in manufacturing, heavy industry, healthcare, and financial services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.afr.com/brand/business-summit/sangeet-choudary-on-amazons-wakeup-call-for-business-20180305-h0x1yq|title=Sangeet Choudary on Amazon's wake-up call for business|date=2018-03-06|work=Financial Review|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Choudary credits game design theory as one of the inspirations for his work on platform design.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businesstoday.in/magazine/features/how-platforms-will-become-critical-for-businesses/story/218895.html#|title=How platforms will become critical for businesses- Business News|website=www.businesstoday.in|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref>
Choudary has been a sought after expert for research outlets including the International Labor Organization,<ref name=":17" /> the MIT Technology Review,<ref name=":11" /> the World Economic Forum,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reports.weforum.org/digital-transformation/wp-content/blogs.dir/94/mp/files/pages/files/white-paper-dti-2017-mm.pdf|title=World Economic Forum - Digital Transformation Initiative|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/GITR2016/WEF_GITR_Full_Report.pdf|title=World Economic Forum - Global Information Technology Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the Economist,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.economist.com/news/business/21678774-europes-biggest-economy-rightly-worried-digitisation-threat-its-industrial|title=Does Deutschland do digital?|website=The Economist|access-date=2018-01-15}}</ref> McKinsey & Company,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/fashion-tech/online-giants-get-personal|title=Online Giants Get Personal|date=2017-12-06|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-01-03|language=en-GB}}</ref> and the European Parliament.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2016/558777/EPRS_STU(2016)558777_EN.pdf|title=European Parliament - The cost of Non-Europe in the Sharing Economy|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://espas.eu/orbis/sites/default/files/generated/document/en/EPRS_STU%282017%29603263_EN.pdf|title=European Parliament - Global Trends to 2035|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
For his work on platform economics, Choudary has been hailed as a 'global thought leader on the platform business model' by Forbes<ref name=":19" /> and a 'top global thinker' by the Huffington Post.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/interview-with-sangeet-choudary-lessons-from-airbnb_us_5962fd55e4b08f5c97d06b05|title=Top Global Thinker Applies Lessons from Airbnb and Uber to Open Government as a Platform|last=Cabrera|first=Marquis|date=2017-07-10|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-13}}</ref>
==Impact on public policy== Choudary has worked with several governments and policy makers in Europe to help them develop competitive and regulatory responses to global platforms entering Europe.<ref name=":13" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.afr.com/brand/business-summit/why-amazon-and-uber-are-working-on-the-dark-side-and-need-to-be-regulated-20180303-h0wydb|title=Amazon and Uber, and the dark side of platforms|date=2018-03-04|work=Financial Review|access-date=2018-03-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fd.nl/morgen/1248528/europa-kan-platforms-als-amazon-reguleren|title=Cookiewall {{!}} Het Financieele Dagblad|website=fd.nl|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
Choudary has been a prominent advocate of individual rights in the platform economy and has worked extensively with several international bodies, including the United Nations, on this topic. His research on worker exploitation by labor platforms was released by the [[International Labour Organization|International Labor Organization]]<ref name=":16" /> as part of their Future of Work Research Paper Series.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/future-of-work/publications/research-papers/WCMS_630603/lang--en/index.htm|title=The architecture of digital labour platforms: Policy recommendations on platform design for worker well-being|date=2018-05-15|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> In November 2017, Choudary addressed a high-level seminar by the Permanent Mission of Belgium in Geneva, highlighting the factors that lead to exploitation of workers on digital platforms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilo.org/global/topics/future-of-work/news/WCMS_583490/lang--en/index.htm|title=High-level seminar on the “Sharing Economy and its Social Challenges”|date=2017-10-16|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}}</ref> In February 2018, Choudary addressed the [[Folketing|Parliament of Denmark]] on labor policy for the platform economy, stressing on the need for a new data-driven regulation paradigm for platforms.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://borsen.dk/opinion/blogs/view/17/5033/derfor_skader_digitale_arbejdsplatforme_kun_de_dovne.html|title=Er den danske model klar til fremtidens digitale arbejdsmarked?|website=borsen.dk|language=da|access-date=2018-05-19}}</ref> His recommendations for regulating platforms through open data sharing were instrumental in informing the Danish government's decision to implement open data regulation for Airbnb in May 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-44166174|title=Airbnb tax evaders targeted in landmark deal|date=2018-05-18|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Choudary's research on the adverse impact of platforms on the creative economy was featured as a keynote at the annual conference of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/meetings/en/2018/global_digital_conference.html|title=WIPO Conference on the Global Digital Content Market: Focus on Asia-Pacific|website=www.wipo.int|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}}</ref> His recommendations advocated the role of the WIPO as a standards setting organization in a platform economy, for protection of creator interests.
Choudary's work on digital trade includes a future positioning paper for countries like Singapore that is widely considered a blueprint for Singapore's strategy for digital trade.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/spore-must-think-like-a-platform-to-thrive-as-a-digital-hub|title=Singapore must think like a platform to thrive as a digital hub|last=hermes|date=2018-02-14|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}}</ref> The paper suggests that countries can adopt a platform strategy and establish free data ports to harness digital trade flows. ==Publications== ===Books=== * ''Platform Revolution'' (2016, with Geoffrey G. Parker and Marshall van Alstyne), [[W. W. Norton & Company]]<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> * ''Platform Scale: How an emerging business model helps startups build large empires with minimum investment'' (2015)<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> * ''HBR's 10 Must Reads 2017: The Definitive Management Ideas of the Year from Harvard Business Review'' (2016, as contributing author, [[Harvard Business Review]])<ref name=":1" /> * ''Managing Startups: Best Blog Posts'' (2013, as contributing author, [[O'Reilly Media]])<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.sg/books?id=-H79V08oykcC&pg=PA67&lpg=PA67&dq=%22managing+startups%22+%22sangeet+paul+choudary%22&source=bl&ots=0hf5lJEujl&sig=azuRqjou05f5HNi4iTTFPHuNYmE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjfwMm98srTAhVEN48KHYpyAZo4ChDoAQgqMAI#v=onepage&q=%22managing%20startups%22%20%22sangeet%20paul%20choudary%22&f=false|title=Managing Startups: Best Blog Posts|last=Eisenmann|first=Thomas|date=2013-05-01|publisher="O'Reilly Media, Inc."|isbn=9781449370503|language=en}}</ref> * ''Dear CEO: 50 Personal Letters from the World's Leading Business Thinkers'' (2017, as contributing author, [[Bloomsbury Publishing]])<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/dear-ceo-9781472950680|title=Dear CEO|last=Bloomsbury.com|website=Bloomsbury Publishing|language=en|access-date=2017-05-22}}</ref>
===Selected papers=== * ''Pipelines, Platforms, and the New Rules of Strategy'' (with Geoffrey G. Parker and Marshall van Alstyne, April 2016), [[Harvard Business Review]]<ref name=":0" /> * ''The architecture of digital labour platforms: Policy recommendations on platform design for worker well-being'', [[International Labour Organization|International Labor Organization (ILO)]]<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---dgreports/---cabinet/documents/publication/wcms_630603.pdf|title=International Labor Organization|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":17" /> * ''Freelancers on the network'', [[MIT Technology Review]]<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/541581/freelancers-on-the-network/|title=Freelancers on the Network|last=Choudary|first=Sangeet Paul|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2017-04-30|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Choudary, Sangeet Paul}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singaporean businesspeople]] [[Category:Indian business writers]] [[Category:Singaporean people of Indian descent]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Use of marketing theory, skills and practices to achieve social change}} {{distinguish|societal marketing|social selling|social media marketing}} {{marketing}} '''Social marketing''' is the use of marketing theory, skills and practices to achieve social change.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/social-marketing.html|title=What is social marketing? definition and meaning|website=BusinessDictionary.com|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> It has the primary goal of achieving "[[Common good|social good]]". Traditional [[commercial marketing]] aims are primarily financial, though they can have positive social affects as well. In the context of public health, social marketing would promote general health, raise awareness and induce changes in behaviour. To see social marketing as only the use of standard commercial marketing practices to achieve non-commercial goals is an [[oversimplification|oversimplified view]].
Social marketing seeks to develop and integrate [[marketing]] concepts with other approaches to [[social change]]. Social marketing aims to influence behaviors that benefit individuals and communities for the greater social good. The goal is to deliver competition-sensitive and segmented social change programs that are effective, efficient, equitable and sustainable.<ref>{{citation|authors=International Social Marketing Association, European Social Marketing Association & Australian Association of Social Marketing|year=2013|title=Consensus Definition of Social Marketing|accessdate=}}</ref>
Increasingly, social marketing is described as having "two parents." The "social parent" uses [[social science]] and [[social policy]] approaches. The "marketing parent" uses commercial and public sector [[marketing]] approaches.<ref>{{cite book|last=Truss|first=Aiden|title=Social Marketing and Public Health: Theory and practice|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CsEijRnC8GYC|editor=Jeff French |editor2=Clive Blair-Stevens |editor3=Dominic McVey |editor4=Rowena Merritt}}</ref> Recent years have also witnessed a broader focus. Social marketing now goes beyond influencing individual behaviour. It promotes socio-cultural and structural change relevant to social issues.<ref name="Strategic Social Marketing">{{cite book|last1=French|first1=Jeff|last2=Gordon|first2=Ross|title=Strategic Social Marketing|date=2015|publisher=Sage|isbn=9781446248621|url=https://uk.sagepub.com/en-gb/eur/strategic-social-marketing/book237965}}</ref> Consequently, social marketing scholars are beginning to advocate for a broader definition of social marketing: "social marketing is the application of marketing principles to enable individual and collective ideas and actions in the pursuit of effective, efficient, equitable, fair and sustained social transformation". The new emphasis gives equal weight to the effects (efficiency and effectiveness) and the process (equity, fairness and sustainability) of social marketing programs.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Saunders, S. G.|author2=Barrington, D. J.|author3=Sridharan, S.|lastauthoramp=y|year=2015|title=Redefining social marketing: beyond behavioural change|journal=Journal of Social Marketing|volume=5|issue=2|pages=160–168|doi=10.1108/JSOCM-03-2014-0021}}</ref>
==Applications == The first documented evidence of the deliberate use of marketing to address a social issue comes from a 1963 [[reproductive health]] program led by [[K. T. Chandy]] at the Indian Institute of Management in Calcutta, India. Chandy and colleagues proposed, and subsequently implemented, a national [[family planning]] program with high quality, government brand condoms distributed and sold throughout the country at low cost. The program included an integrated consumer marketing campaign run with active point of sale promotion. Retailers were trained to sell the product aggressively, and a new organization was created to implement the program.<ref>Chandy, K.T., Balakrishman, T.R., Kantawalla, J.M., Mohan, K., Sen, N.P., Gupta, S.S. & Srivastva, S. (1965). Proposals for family planning promotion: A marketing plan. Studies in Family Planning;1(6):7-12.</ref> In [[Developing country|developing countries]], the use of social marketing expanded to [[Prevention of HIV/AIDS|HIV prevention]], control of childhood [[diarrhea]] (through the use of [[Oral rehydration therapy|oral re-hydration therapies]]), [[malaria]] control and treatment, [[Portable water purification|point-of-use water treatment]], [[Self-supply of water and sanitation|on-site sanitation]] methods and the provision of basic health services.<ref>Lefebvre, R. C. (2011). An integrative model for social marketing. Journal of Social Marketing;1:54–72.</ref>
Health promotion campaigns began applying social marketing in practice in the 1980s. In the United States, The National High Blood Pressure Education Program<ref>Roccella, E.J. & Ward, G.W. (1984). The National High Blood Pressure Education Program: A description of its utility as a generic program model. Health Education Quarterly, 11(3): 225-242</ref> and the community heart disease prevention studies in Pawtucket, Rhode Island and at Stanford University<ref name="Lefebvre1988">Lefebvre, R.C. & Flora, J.A. (1988). Social Marketing and Public Health Intervention (Portable Document Format). Health Education Quarterly; 15 (3): 300, 301.</ref> demonstrated the effectiveness of the approach to address population-based risk factor behaviour change. Notable early developments also took place in Australia. These included the Victoria Cancer Council developing its [[smoking cessation|anti-tobacco]] campaign "Quit" (1988) and "SunSmart" (1988), its campaign against [[skin cancer]] which had the slogan "[[Slip-Slop-Slap|Slip! Slop! Slap!]]"<ref name="VicHealth">{{cite web |url=http://www.vichealth.vic.gov.au/en/About-VicHealth/VicHealth-History-Major-Events-and-Milestones.aspx |title=VicHealth History: Major Events and Milestones |work=VicHealth |publisher=Victorian Health Promotion Foundation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090719032451/http://www.vichealth.vic.gov.au/en/About-VicHealth/VicHealth-History-Major-Events-and-Milestones.aspx |archivedate=2009-07-19 |df= }}</ref>
Since the 1980s, the field has rapidly expanded around the world to include active living communities, disaster preparedness and response, [[ecosystem]] and species conservation, environmental issues, development of volunteer or indigenous workforces, financial literacy, global threats of [[Antimicrobial resistance|antibiotic resistance]], government corruption, improving the quality of health care, injury prevention, landowner education, [[marine conservation]] and ocean sustainability, patient-centered health care, reducing health disparities, [[sustainable consumption]], transportation demand management, [[water treatment]] and [[sanitation]] systems and youth gambling problems, among other social needs (See<ref>Lefebvre, R.C. (2013) Social marketing and social change: Strategies and tools for improving health, well-being and the environment. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass.</ref><ref name="Lefebvre, R.C. 2013">Lefebvre, R.C. (Ed). Social marketing: Six volume set. London: SAGE Publications, 2013.</ref>).
On a wider front, by 2007, government in the United Kingdom announced the development of its first social marketing strategy for all aspects of health.<ref name="DeptofHealth2004">UK Department of Health, ''[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_4094550 Choosing Health: Making Healthy Choices Easier]'', Cmd.6374 2004.</ref> In 2010, the US national health objectives<ref name="HealthyPeople2020">US Department of Health and Human Services, ''[http://healthypeople.gov/2020/topicsobjectives2020/objectiveslist.aspx?topicId=18 Health Communication and Health Information Technology]''</ref> included increasing the number of state health departments that report using social marketing in health promotion and disease prevention programs and increasing the number of schools of public health that offer courses and workforce development activities in social marketing.
Two other public health applications include the CDC's CDCynergy training and software application<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthmarketing/cdcynergy/ |title=CDC - CDCynergy (NCHM) |accessdate=2007-10-19 |date=2006-06-27 |publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention}}</ref> and SMART (Social Marketing and Assessment Response Tool) in the U.S.<ref name="SMART">{{cite journal |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0CTG/is_2-3_18/ai_108194963/ |title=Positioning Social Marketing as a Planning Process for Health Education |accessdate=2012-01-13 |last= Neiger |first=Brad L. |author2=Rosemary Thackeray |author3=Michael D. Barnes |author4= James F. McKenzie |year=2003 |journal=American Journal of Health Studies |volume=18 |issue=2/3 |pages=75–81 }}</ref>
Social marketing theory and practice has been progressed in several countries such as the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the UK, and in the latter a number of key government policy papers have adopted a strategic social marketing approach. Publications such as "Choosing Health" in 2004,<ref name="DeptofHealth2004"/> "[http://www.nsmcentre.org.uk/component/remository/NSMC-Publications/Its-Our-Health-%28Summary-Report%29/ It's our health!]" in 2006 and "[http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_4139514 Health Challenge England]" in 2006, represent steps to achieve a strategic and operational use of social marketing. In India, [[AIDS]] controlling programs are largely using social marketing and social workers are largely working for it. Most of the social workers are professionally trained for this task.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}
A variation of social marketing has emerged as a systematic way to foster more sustainable behavior. Referred to as community-based social marketing (CBSM) by Canadian environmental psychologist Doug McKenzie-Mohr, CBSM strives to change the behavior of communities to reduce their impact on the environment.<ref>McKenzie-Mohr, D. (2000). Fostering sustainable behavior through community-based social marketing. American Psychologist, 55(5), 531-537.</ref> Realizing that simply providing information is usually not sufficient to initiate behavior change, CBSM uses tools and findings from social psychology to discover the perceived barriers to behavior change and ways of overcoming these barriers. Among the tools and techniques used by CBSM are focus groups and surveys (to discover barriers) and commitments, prompts, social norms, social diffusion, feedback and incentives (to change behavior). The tools of CBSM have been used to foster sustainable behavior in many areas, including energy conservation,<ref>Schultz P. W., Nolan J. M., Cialdini R. B., Goldstein N. J., Griskevicius Vladas (2007). The Constructive, Destructive, and Reconstructive Power of Social Norms. ''Psychological Science'', 18(5), 429-434.</ref> environmental regulation<ref>Kennedy, A. (2010). Using Community-Based Social Marketing Techniques to Enhance Environmental Regulation. ''Sustainability'', 2(4), 1138-1160</ref> and recycling.<ref>Haldeman, T. & Turner, J. (2009). Implementing a community-based social marketing program to increase recycling. ''Social Marketing Quarterly'', 15(3), 114-127.</ref>
In recent years, the concept of strategic social marketing has emerged, which identifies that social change requires action at the individual, community, socio-cultural, political and environmental level, and that social marketing can and should influence policy, strategy and operational tactics to achieve pro-social outcomes.<ref name="Strategic Social Marketing"/>
Other social marketing can be aimed at products deemed, at least by proponents, as socially unacceptable. One of the most notable is [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) which for many years has waged social marketing campaigns against the use of natural fur products. The campaigns' efficacy has been subject to dispute.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peek|first=Liz|title=Warm Weather Torments City Furriers|url=http://www.nysun.com/business/warm-weather-torments-city-furriers/43889/|accessdate=12 March 2013|newspaper=New York Sun|date=November 21, 2006}}</ref>
Not all social marketing campaigns are effective everywhere. For example, anti-smoking campaigns such as [[World No Tobacco Day]] while being successful (in concert with government tobacco controls) in curbing the demand for tobacco products in North America and in parts of Europe, have been less effective in other parts of the world such as China, India and Russia.<ref>Andrei Fedyashin, [Opinion & Analysis: World No Tobacco Day, Futile Attempt to Curb Smoking. http://en.rian.ru/analysis/20090529/155119204.html], RiaNovosti (Russia), May 29, 2009</ref> (See also: [[Prevalence of tobacco consumption]])
==Types == Social marketing uses the benefits of doing social good to secure and maintain [[customer engagement]]. In social marketing the distinguishing feature is therefore its "primary focus on social good, and it is not a secondary outcome.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} Not all public sector and not-for-profit marketing is social marketing.
Public sector bodies can use standard marketing approaches to improve the promotion of their relevant services and organizational aims. This can be very important but should not be confused with social marketing where the focus is on achieving specific behavioral goals with specific audiences in relation to topics relevant to social good (e.g., health, sustainability, recycling, etc.). For example, a 3-month marketing campaign to encourage people to get a H1N1 vaccine is more tactical in nature and should not be considered social marketing. A campaign that promotes and reminds people to get regular check-ups and all of their vaccinations when they're supposed to encourages a long-term behavior change that benefits society. It can therefore be considered social marketing.
Social marketing can be confused with commercial marketing. A commercial marketer may only seek to influence a buyer to purchase a product. Social marketers have more difficult goals. They want to make potentially difficult and long-term behavior changes in target populations, which may or may not involve purchasing a product. For example, reducing cigarette smoking or encouraging use of condoms have difficult challenges to overcome that go beyond purchasing decisions.
Social marketing is sometimes seen as being restricted to a client base of non-profit organizations, health services groups, the government agency. However, the goal of inducing social change is not restricted to this narrow spectrum of organizations. Corporations, for example, can be clients. Public relations or social responsibility departments may champion social causes such funding for the arts, which would involve social marketing.
Social marketing should not be confused with the societal marketing concept which was a forerunner of [[sustainable marketing]] in integrating issues of [[corporate social responsibility|social responsibility]] into commercial marketing strategies. In contrast to that, social marketing uses commercial marketing theories, tools and techniques to social issues.
Social marketing applies a "customer oriented" approach and uses the concepts and tools used by commercial marketers in pursuit of social goals like anti-smoking campaigns or fund raising for NGOs.
Social marketers must create competitive advantage by constantly adapting to and instigating change. With climate change in mind, adaptations to market changes are likely to be more successful if actions are guided by knowledge of the forces shaping market behaviours and insights that enable the development of sustainable competitive advantages.<ref>Shocker, Allan D., Rajendra K. Srivastava, and Robert W. Ruekert. "Challenges and Opportunities Facing Brand Management: An Introduction to the Special Issue." Journal of Marketing Research 31.2 (1994): 149. Web.</ref>
==Confusion== In 2006, [[Jupitermedia]] announced its "Social Marketing" service,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://socialmarketing.blogs.com/r_craiig_lefebvres_social/2006/08/hello_jupiter_a.html |title=Hello Jupiter? Anyone Home? |accessdate=2006-09-01 |last=Lefebvre |first=R. Craig |date=2006-08-30 |work=On Marketing and Social Change}}</ref> with which it aims to enable website owners to profit from [[social media]]. Despite protests from the social marketing communities over the perceived hijacking of the term, Jupiter stuck with the name.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://weblogs.jupiterresearch.com/analysts/schatsky/archives/016969.html |title=Social Marketing vs. Social Marketing |accessdate=2006-09-01 |last=Schatsky |first=David |date=2006-09-01 |work=Jupiterresearch Analyst Weblogs |publisher=Jupitermedia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070303050738/http://weblogs.jupiterresearch.com/analysts/schatsky/archives/016969.html |archivedate=2007-03-03 |df= }}</ref> However, Jupiter's approach is more correctly (and commonly) referred to as [[social media optimization]].
==History ==
Many scholars ascribe the beginning of the field of social marketing to an article published by G.D. Wiebe in the Winter 1951-1952 edition of ''[[Public Opinion Quarterly]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wiebe|first=G.D.|title=Merchandising Commodities and Citizenship on Television|journal=Public Opinion Quarterly|year=1951–1952|volume=15|issue=Winter|pages=679|doi=10.1086/266353}}</ref> In it, Wiebe posed a rhetorical question: "Why can’t you sell brotherhood and rational thinking like you can sell soap?” He then went on to discuss what he saw as the challenges of attempting to sell a social good as if it were a commodity, thus identifying social marketing (though he did not label it as such) as a discipline unique from c mmodity marketing. Yet, Wilkie & Moore (2003)<ref>Wilkie, W. L., & Moore, E. S. (2003). Scholarly research in marketing: Exploring the “4 eras” of thought development. Journal of Public Policy & Marketing; 22(2):116–146.</ref> note that the marketing discipline has been involved with questions about the intersection of marketing and society since its earliest days as a discipline.
A decade later, organizations such as the [[KfW Entwicklungsbank]] in Germany, the Canadian International Development Agency, the Ministry for Foreign Affairs in The Netherlands, UK Department for International Development, [[US Agency for International Development]], [[World Health Organization]] and the [[World Bank]] began sponsoring social marketing interventions to improve family planning and achieve other social goals in Africa, Sri Lanka, and elsewhere.<ref>{{cite book|last=Baker|first=Michael|title=The Marketing Book|year=2012|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|location=Oxford|pages=696}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Lefebvre|first=R. Craig|title=Social Marketing and Social Change: Strategies and Tools to Improve Health, Well-Being and the Environment\year=2013|publisher=Jossey-Bass|location=San Francisco|pages=4}}</ref>
The next milestone in the evolution of social marketing was the publication of "Social Marketing: An Approach to Planned Social Change" in the ''[[Journal of Marketing]]'' by [[Philip Kotler]] and [[Gerald Zaltman]].<ref name="Kotler 1971">{{cite journal|last=Kotler|first=Philip|author2=Gerald Zaltman |title=Social Marketing: An Approach to Planned Social Change|journal=Journal of Marketing|date=July 1971|volume=35|pages=3–12|url=https://www.sfu.ca/cmns/faculty/laba_m/425/07-fall/documents/Kotler-Zaltman.PDF|doi=10.2307/1249783}}</ref> Kotler and Zaltman coined the term 'social marketing' and defined it as "the design, implementation, and control of programs calculated to influence the acceptability of social ideas and involving considerations of product planning, pricing, communication, distribution, and marketing research." They conclude that "social marketing appears to represent a bridging mechanism which links the behavior scientist's knowledge of human behavior with the socially useful implementation of what that knowledge allows."
Craig Lefebvre and June Flora introduced social marketing to the public health community in 1988,<ref name="Lefebvre1988"/> where it has been most widely used and explored. They noted that there was a need for "large scale, broad-based, behavior change focused programs" to improve public health (the community wide prevention of cardiovascular diseases in their respective projects) and outlined eight essential components of social marketing that still hold today: #A consumer orientation to realize organizational (social) goals #An emphasis on the voluntary exchanges of goods and services between providers and consumers #Research in audience analysis and segmentation strategies #The use of formative research in product and message design and the pretesting of these materials #An analysis of distribution (or communication) channels #Use of the [[marketing mix]]—using and blending product, price, place and promotion characteristics in intervention planning and implementation #A process tracking system with both integrative and control functions #A management process that involves problem analysis, planning, implementation and feedback functions<ref name="Lefebvre">{{cite journal |last=Lefebvre |first=R. Craig |author2=June A. Flora |year=1988 |title=Social Marketing and Public Health Intervention |journal=Health Education Quarterly |volume=15 |issue=3 |pages=300, 301 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |url=http://socialmarketing.blogs.com/Publications/Social_Marketing_and_Public_Health_Intervention.pdf |format=Portable Document Format |accessdate=2008-04-30 |doi=10.1177/109019818801500305}}</ref>
Speaking of what they termed "social change campaigns", Kotler and [[Ned Roberto]] introduced the subject by writing, "A social change campaign is an organized effort conducted by one group (the change agent) which attempts to persuade others (the target adopters) to accept, modify, or abandon certain ideas, attitudes, practices or behavior." Their 1989 text was updated in 2002 by [[Philip Kotler]], [[Ned Roberto]] and Nancy Lee.<ref name="Kotler2002">Kotler, Philip, Ned Roberto and Nancy Lee. ''Social Marketing: Improving the Quality of Life'', SAGE, 2002. ({{ISBN|0-7619-2434-5}})</ref> In 2005, [[University of Stirling]] was the first university to open a dedicated research institute to Social Marketing,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ism.stir.ac.uk/|title=Institute for Social Marketing – University of Stirling|author=|date=|website=www.ism.stir.ac.uk|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> while in 2007, [[Middlesex University]] became the first university to offer a specialized [[postgraduate]] programme in Health & Social Marketing.<ref>Source: {{cite web|url=http://www.mdx.ac.uk/courses/postgraduate/marketing/health_soc_marketing_ma.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524003618/http://www.mdx.ac.uk/courses/postgraduate/marketing/health_soc_marketing_ma.aspx |archivedate=2010-05-24 |df= }}</ref>
In recent years there has been an important development to distinguish between "strategic social marketing" and "operational social marketing".
Much of the literature and case examples focus on operational social marketing, using it to achieve specific behavioral goals in relation to different audiences and topics. However, there has been increasing efforts to ensure social marketing goes "upstream" and is used much more strategically to inform policy formulation and strategy development. Here the focus is less on specific audience and topic work but uses strong customer understanding and insight to inform and guide effective policy and strategy development.
Social marketing is also being explored as a method for social innovation, a framework to increase the adoption of evidence-based practices among professionals and organizations, and as a core skill for public sector managers and social entrepreneurs. It is being viewed as an approach to design more effective, efficient, equitable and sustainable approaches to enhance social well-being that extends beyond individual behavior change to include creating positive shifts in social networks and social norms, businesses, markets and public policy.<ref>Lefebvre, R.C. (2013). Social marketing and social change: Strategies and tools for improving health, well-being and the environment. San Francisco: Jossey-Bass.</ref>
Many examples exist of social marketing research, with over 120 papers compiled in a six volume set.<ref name="Lefebvre, R.C. 2013"/>). For example, research now shows ways to reduce the intentions of people to binge drink or engage in dangerous driving. Martin, Lee, Weeks and Kaya (2013) suggests that understanding consumer personality and how people view others is important. People were shown ads talking of the harmful effects of binge drinking. People who valued close friends as a sense of who they are were less likely to want to binge drink after seeing an ad featuring them and a close friend. People who were loners or who did not see close friends important to their sense of who they were reacted better to ads featuring an individual. A similar pattern was shown for ads showing a person driving at dangerous speeds. This suggests ads showing potential harm to citizens from binge drinking or dangerous driving are less effective than ads highlighting a person’s close friends.<ref>Martin, Brett A. S., Christina K.C. Lee, Clinton Weeks and Maria Kaya (2013), [http://www.basmartin.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Martin-et-al.-2013.pdf "How to stop binge drinking and speeding motorists: Effects of relational-interdependent self-construable and self-referencing on attitudes toward social marketing "] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427160914/http://www.basmartin.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/Martin-et-al.-2013.pdf |date=2015-04-27 }}, ''Journal of Consumer Behavior'', 12, 81-90.</ref>
==See also== {{main|List of topics related to public relations and propaganda}}
* [[Agenda-setting theory]] * [[Cause-related marketing]] * [[Development communication]] * [[Financial literacy]] * [[Health promotion]] * [[Jay Winsten]] * [[Media intelligence]] * [[The Tipping Point]]

==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Andreasen |first=Alan R. |title=Marketing Social Change: Changing Behavior to Promote Health, Social Development, and the Environment |publisher=Jossey-Bass |date=October 1995 |isbn=0-7879-0137-7 }} *{{cite book|last1=French|first1=Jeff|last2=Gordon|first2=Ross|title=Strategic Social Marketing|date=2015|publisher=Sage|isbn=9781446248621|url=https://uk.sagepub.com/en-gb/eur/strategic-social-marketing/book237965}} * {{cite book |last=Harvey |first=Philip D. |title=Let Every Child Be Wanted: How Social Marketing is Revolutionizing Contraceptive Use Around the World |publisher=Auburn House|year=1999 |isbn= 0-86569-282-3}} * {{cite book |last=Hastings |first=Gerard |title=Social Marketing - Why Should the Devil Have All the Best Tunes? |publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann |date=July 2007 |isbn= 0-7506-8350-3}} * Journal of Social Marketing - https://www.emeraldinsight.com/journal/jsocm * Kaplan Andreas M., Haenlein Michael (2009) The increasing importance of public marketing: Explanations, applications and limits of marketing within public administration, European Management Journal. * {{cite book|last=Lee|first=Nancy|title=Social Marketing: Influencing Behaviors for Good|year=2011|isbn=978-1412981491|author2=Philip Kotler }} * {{cite book|last=Lefebvre|first=R. Craig|title=Social Marketing: A Six Volume Set|year=2013|isbn=978-1446253113}} * {{cite book|last=Lefebvre|first=R. Craig|title=Social Marketing and Social Change: Strategies and Tools for Improving Health, Well-Being and the Environment|year=2013|isbn= 978-0-470-93684-9}} * {{cite book |last=McKenzie-Mohr |first=Doug |author2=William Smith |title=Fostering Sustainable Behavior: An Introduction to Community-Based Social Marketing |isbn=0-86571-406-1}} * [[Social Marketing Quarterly]] (SMQ) - smq.sagepub.com * {{cite book |last=Weinreich |first=Nedra Kline |title=Hands-On Social Marketing: A Step-by-Step Guide to Designing Change for Good (2nd Edition) |publisher=Sage Publications |date=October 2010 |isbn=0-7619-0867-6}}
==External links== {{external links|date=August 2013}} * [http://www.aasm.org.au Australian Association of Social Marketing] * [http://www.emeraldinsight.com/loi/jsocm?id=jsocm Journal of Social Marketing] * [https://www.cdc.gov/healthmarketing National Center for Health Marketing] at the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050725075721/http://www.social-marketing.org/ Social Marketing Institute] (SMI) at [[Georgetown University]] * [http://www.ism.stir.ac.uk Institute for Social Marketing] at the [[University of Stirling]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070408142307/http://aef.com/on_campus/symposia/2005/3000 The Advertising Industry's Commitment to Social Responsibility and Children's Health and Wellness] - a 2005 symposium by the Advertising Educational Foundation * [http://smq.sagepub.com Social Marketing Quarterly] (SMQ) - an [[academic journal]] on social marketing

[[ru:Социальный маркетинг]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2016}} The '''Sri Lanka Administrative Service (SLAS)''' is the key administrative service of the [[Government of Sri Lanka]], with civil servants working for both in the Central Government as well as in the provincial councils... It was formed as the ''Ceylon Administrative Service'' (CAS) in 1963 as the successor to the [[Ceylon Civil Service]] which was abolished on May 1, 1963. It is the senior of the [[Public Services of Sri Lanka|public service]]s.
Based on the [[British Civil Service]] the SLAS is the permanent [[bureaucracy]] that helps the elected officials on day-to-day functions of government. They are selected, promoted by the [[Civil service commission|Public Service Commission]]. But top positions in the government such as Permanent Secretaries are appointed by the President, in theory on the recommendations of the Public Service Commission.
A Permanent Secretary is the top bureaucrat of the government ministry and is responsible for the day-to-day functions of the ministry whereas in theory the [[Minister (government)|minister]] is responsible only for drafting policy. The head of the SLAS is the [[Presidential Secretariat|Secretary to the President]].
A Chief Secretary is a Special Grade officer of the Sri Lanka Administrative Service in the provinces which is equivalent to a Permanent Secretary of the central government known as Chief Secretary. There are nine Chief Secretaries, one for each of the [[Provinces of Sri Lanka|nine provinces]].
==Grading schemes== Until 2005, broader term officers are classed into SLAS class 1 officers, SLAS class 2 grade 1, and SLAS class 2 grade 2. All grades from SLAS class 1 and above (see table) are part of the "Senior officers ". The [[Secretary to the Treasury (Sri lanka)|Secretary to the Treasury]] was the traditional head of the Civil Service during the time of the old [[Ceylon Civil Service]], but in years after the establishment of the SLAS the Presidents Secretary is the de facto head of the SLAS.
After 1 January 2005 Sri Lanka Administrative service introduced four grades, such as: * Special Grade offices (present cadre is 200) * Class I officers (present cadre is 507) * Class II officers (present cadre is 639) * Class III officers (present cadre is 1059)
Below the "Senior officers "(Special Grade offices, Class I officers and ), each individual department can put in place its own grading.
The traditional titles for each grade of the civil service are as follows:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Traditional Title !! Alternative Title !! Grade |- | [[Presidential Secretariat|Secretary to the President]] || [[Secretary to the Treasury (Sri lanka)|Secretary to the Treasury]] ||Special Grade offices |- | [[Permanent Secretary]] || Chief Secretary ||Special Grade officers |- | Additional Secretary || [[Commissioner-General]], [[Director-General]] ||Special Grade officers |- | Senior Assistant Secretary || [[Commissioner]], Director ||Class I officers |- | Assistant Secretary || Deputy Commissioner, Deputy Director ||Class II officers |- | Titles vary widely || Assistant Commissioner, Assistant Director ||Class II officers |}
* The post of Deputy Secretary is only used in the Ministry of Finance is ranked just below the post of Permanent Secretary.
==Notable members of the SLAS== *[[R.Paskaralingam]] *[[Nissanka Wijeyeratne]] *[[Ronnie De Mel]] *[[Bradman Weerakoon]] *[[Sarath Amunugama (politician)|Sarath Amunugama]] *[[Sanath Weerakoon]] *[[Prematilaka Mapitigama]] *[[Lalith Weeratunga]] *[[P.B. Abeykoon]]
==See also== *[[Public Services of Sri Lanka]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Virginia State Senators]] to [[Category:Virginia state senators]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 17]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{about|the U.S. Senator from Virginia| his grandson, the first governor of Michigan|Stevens T. Mason}} {{Infobox Senator |honorific-prefix = |name = Stevens Thomson Mason |honorific-suffix = |image = Sthmason.jpg |imagesize = 200px |jr/sr=United States Senator |state = [[Virginia]] |term_start = November 18, 1794 |term_end = May 10, 1803 |preceded = [[James Monroe]] |succeeded = [[John Taylor of Caroline|John Taylor]] |office2 = Member of the [[Virginia Senate]] from [[Loudoun County, Virginia|Loudoun]] and [[Fauquier County, Virginia|Fauquier]] Counties |term2 = 1787–1791 |office3 = Member of the [[Virginia House of Delegates]] from Loudoun County |term3 = 1794 |term4 = 1783–1784 | birth_date ={{Birth date|1760|12|29}} | birth_place =[[Chopawamsic (plantation)|Chopawamsic]], [[Stafford County, Virginia|Stafford County]], [[Colony of Virginia]] | death_date ={{Death date and age|1803|5|10|1760|12|29}} | death_place =[[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] | nationality = | party = [[Anti-Administration Party (United States)|Anti-Administration Party]]
[[Democratic-Republican Party]] | spouse = Mary Elizabeth Armistead | relations = | children = [[John Thomson Mason (1787–1850)|John Thomson Mason]]
[[Armistead Thomson Mason]]
Stevens Thomson Mason
Mary Thomson Mason
Emily Rutger Mason
Catherine Mason | residence = | alma_mater =[[The College of William & Mary]] | occupation = [[lawyer]] | profession = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Stevens Thomson Mason''' (December 29, 1760{{spaced ndash}}May 10, 1803){{cite web | url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/library/masonweb/p26.htm#i1292 | title=Stevens Thomson Mason | accessdate=2009-11-14 | publisher=Gunston Hall | author=Gunston Hall | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115155026/http://www.gunstonhall.org/library/masonweb/p26.htm#i1292 | archivedate=2010-01-15 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://politicalgraveyard.com/families/10855.html | title=Mason family of Virginia | date= 16 June 2008| accessdate=2009-03-07 | publisher=The Political Graveyard | author=The Political Graveyard}} was a Colonel in the [[Continental Army]] during the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]], a member of the [[Virginia]] state legislature and a [[Democratic-Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[U.S. Senator]] from Virginia (1794–1803). ==Early life and military career== Mason was born at [[Chopawamsic (plantation)|Chopawamsic]] in [[Stafford County, Virginia]] and attended [[College of William & Mary]] in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]]. He studied law, was admitted to the [[bar (law)|bar]], and commenced practice in [[Dumfries, Virginia]] in [[Prince William County, Virginia]]. He served in the Continental Army as an aide to General [[George Washington]] at the [[Battle of Yorktown (1781)|Battle of Yorktown]] and was a brigadier general in the Virginia Militia. ==Political career== He was a member of the Virginia State House of Delegates in 1783 and 1794, a member of the Virginia State Senate 1787–1790, and a delegate to the Virginia Ratification Convention in 1788. In 1794, Mason was elected to the [[United States Senate]] to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of [[James Monroe]]. He was reelected in 1797 and again in 1803, serving from 18 November 1794, until his death in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. He is interred in the family burying ground at [[Raspberry Plain]] in [[Loudoun County, Virginia]]. ==Marriage and children== Mason married Mary Elizabeth Armistead on May 1, 1783. The couple had six children: *[[John Thomson Mason (1787–1850)|John Thomson Mason]] (January 8, 1787 – April 17, 1850) *[[Armistead Thomson Mason]] (1787 – February 6, 1819) *Stevens Thomson Mason (1789 – 17 November 1815) *Mary Thomson Mason (1791–1813) *Emily Rutger Mason (1793–1837) *Catherine Mason (born 1795) ==Relations== Stevens Thomson Mason was a nephew of [[George Mason]] (1725–1792); son of [[Thomson Mason]] (1733–1785); brother of [[John Thomson Mason]] (1765–1824); half-brother of [[William Temple Thomson Mason]] (1782–1862); first cousin of [[George Mason V]] (1753–1796); first cousin once removed of [[Thomson Francis Mason]] (1785–1838), [[George Mason VI]] (1786–1834), [[Richard Barnes Mason]] (1797–1850), and [[James Murray Mason]] (1798–1871); father of [[Armistead Thomson Mason]] (1787–1819) and [[John Thomson Mason (1787–1850)|John Thomson Mason]] (1787–1850); uncle of [[John Thomson Mason, Jr.]] (1815–1873); and grandfather of [[Stevens T. Mason|Stevens Thomson Mason]] (1811–1843). ==See also== * [[List of United States Congress members who died in office (1790–1899)]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{CongBio|M000226}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-sen}} {{U.S. Senator box|class=1|state=Virginia| before = [[James Monroe]] | after = [[John Taylor of Caroline|John Taylor]] | years =18 November 1794 – 10 May 1803 | alongside=[[Henry Tazewell]], [[Wilson Cary Nicholas|Wilson C. Nicholas]] }} {{s-end}} {{USSenVA}} {{Virginia Masons}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mason, Stevens Thomson}} [[Category:1760 births]] [[Category:1803 deaths]] [[Category:18th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:19th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:British North American Anglicans]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Virginia]] [[Category:Continental Army officers from Virginia]] [[Category:Delegates to the Virginia Ratifying Convention]] [[Category:18th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Democratic-Republican Party United States Senators]] [[Category:Mason family]] [[Category:Members of the Virginia House of Delegates]] [[Category:People from Stafford County, Virginia]] [[Category:College of William & Mary alumni]] [[Category:United States Senators from Virginia]] [[Category:Virginia Democratic-Republicans]] [[Category:Virginia lawyers]] [[Category:Virginia state senators]] [[Category:People from Dumfries, Virginia]]

{{For|the dance move|Dip (dance move)}} {{notability|Books|date=December 2014}}{{Infobox book | name = The Dip | orig title = | translator = | image = File:The dip.jpg | caption = | author = [[Seth Godin]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Self-actualization]], [[Business]], [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = [[Penguin Group]] (USA) | release_date = 2007 (USA) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] & [[Paperback]]) | pages = 86 p. (US hardcover edition) | isbn = 1-59184-166-6 | preceded_by = Small is the New Big | followed_by = Meatball Sundae }}
'''''The Dip: A Little Book That Teaches You When to Quit (and When to Stick)''''' (2007) is the tenth published book by [[Seth Godin]].<ref>The Dip: A Little Book That Teaches You When to Quit (and When to Stick).</ref> It is a 76 page book that illustrates the concept of "the dip"—a temporary setback that can be overcome with persistence—and how to recognize if you are within one worth pushing through or one where you should quit.
==Background== The rough idea for ''The Dip'' first materialized on Godin's blog.<ref name=800CEO>[http://800ceoread.com/blog/archives/006719.html The Dip: A New Book Coming From Seth Godin] on ''800-CEO-READ''. January 22, 2007.</ref> On an entry titled "The four curves of want and get," Godin shows four curves representing patterns of adoption.<ref name=fourcurves>[http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2005/06/the_four_curves.html The four curves of want and get] ''Seth's Blog''. June 24, 2005.</ref> He ends the post with "How do you avoid killing something too early, or celebrating too early. And last, how do you know when to kill a dud," a theme that would reappear in ''The Dip''. Five months later, Godin posted another entry titled "Understanding Local Max," in which he presented another success curve—this time nearly identical to the one that appears in his book—and analyzed the hypothetical conversation that would occur at four points on the curve.<ref>[http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2005/11/understanding_l.html Understanding Local Max] ''Seth's Blog''. November 9, 2005.</ref> In addition to being the basis behind ''The Dip'', the entry was also included in ''Small is the new Big'', a collection of short pieces from his blog.
==Synopsis== Godin introduces the book with a quote from [[Vince Lombardi]]: "Quitters never win and winners never quit." He follows this with "Bad advice. Winners quit all the time. ''They just quit the right stuff at the right time.''"
Godin first makes the assertion that "being the best in the world is seriously underrated," although he defines the term 'best' as "best for them based on what they believe and what they know," and 'world' as "the world they have access to." He supports this by illustrating that [[vanilla]] [[ice cream]] is almost four times as popular as the next-most popular ice cream, further stating that this is seen in [[Zipf's Law]]. Godin's central thesis is that in order to be the best in the world, one must quit the wrong stuff and stick with the right stuff. In illustrating this, Godin introduces several curves: 'the dip,' 'the cul-de-sac,' and 'the cliff.'<ref>[http://sethgodin.typepad.com/the_dip/2007/05/images_from_the.html Images from the book] ''The Dip Blog''. May 20, 2007.</ref> Godin gives examples of the dip, ways to recognize when an apparent dip is really a cul-de-sac, and presents strategies of when to quit, amongst other things.
The book is also accompanied with cartoons from Hugh MacLeod, who publishes his cartoons on his blog ''gapingvoid'' and is the author of "How To Be Creative."<ref>[http://www.gapingvoid.com/ gapingvoid] cartoons drawn on the back of business cards</ref><ref>MacLeod, Hugh [http://www.gapingvoid.com/Moveable_Type/archives/000932.html How To Be Creative] ''gapingvoid''.</ref>
==Release and Reception== In early March, Godin launched a companion [[blog]] to ''The Dip'' titled "The Dip Blog," in which he released details about the book and gave illustrative examples.<ref>[http://sethgodin.typepad.com/the_dip/ The Dip Blog]</ref> On his subsequent book tour, Godin agreed to go to any place where people had bought 2,500 copies of his book.<ref>Windley, Phil [http://www.windley.com/archives/2007/05/seth_godin_the_dip.shtml Seth Godin: The Dip]</ref> Godin made stops in 15 cities, totaling 37,500 books. ''The Dip'' peaked at #5 on the [[New York Times Best Seller List]] and sold 100,000 copies in its first month of release.<ref>[http://www.bestsellerinterviews.com/10-questions-with-seth-godin-author-of-permission-marketing-purple-cow-and-the-dip.html 10 Questions with Seth Godin] ''Bestseller Interviews''. June 8, 2007.</ref>
The book was met with positive reviews, receiving profiles in [[USA Today]], [[The Miami Herald]], [[National Post]], [[South China Morning Post]], [[Brandweek]], and [[Entrepreneur Magazine]].<ref>Francis, Diane [http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/francis/archive/2007/12/26/seth-godin-dig.aspx Seth Godin's the dip is a great little read] ''[[National Post]]''. December 26, 2007.</ref><ref>Gyopos, Susie [http://www.classifiedpost.com.hk/jsarticledetail.php?articleid=3000021739&arttype=READS&communitycode=&message=INVALID-134 The secret's in the timing] ''South China Morning Post''. August 23, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://www.brandweek.com/bw/news/spotlight/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003591177 Q&A: Seth Godin Says 'Know When To Bail'] ''Brandweek''. May 29, 2007.</ref><ref>Tice, Carol [http://www.entrepreneur.com/magazine/entrepreneur/2007/may/177044.html When to Fold 'Em] ''Entrepreneur Magazine''. May 2007.</ref> [[Chris Anderson (writer)|Chris Anderson]], author of ''[[The Long Tail]]'', and [[Guy Kawasaki]] also endorsed the book.<ref>[http://www.longtail.com/the_long_tail/2007/03/googles_case_ag.html Google's case against marketing] ''The Long Tail Blog''. March 21, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://blog.guykawasaki.com/2007/04/the_big_dip_ten.html The Big Dip: Ten Questions with Seth Godin] ''Guy Kawasaki''. April 22, 2007.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
